Foreign Ministry to have new department of sanction policies
330 字
2022 年 10 月 13 日 17:42 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Oct 13 (CTK) - A new department of sanction policies is supposed to be established by January 1 at the Foreign Ministry (MZV), following the new sanction law that could be passed at the current lower house session, Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) told reporters today.

There is also a new department of energy security at the ministry.

Lipavsky said he considered the new department of sanction policies crucial for fulfilling the agenda.

"Right now, other parts of the ministry deal with this and it is not in the gestion of anyone in particular," he said.

The department will have four members and it will cooperate with the security forces, ministries, board of customs as well as the Financial Analytical Office (FAU).

The bill on national sanctions against foreigners who have performed a serious illegal act will probably be passed by the Chamber of Deputies.

The Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended to the lower house that it shorten the period the government has for reviewing the decision to put someone on a sanction list by one third to 30 days. It might also specify the list of regulations based on which a certain act can be considered punishable in accordance with the sanction law.

The government accelerated its presentation due to the conflict in Ukraine.

Recently, a new department of energy security, also comprised of four members, has been established at the ministry.

The Foreign Ministry was the crucial player in preventing Russia from joining the nuclear programme in Czechia and now the same ministry has a key role in replacing the Russian materials in all energy spheres, Vaclav Bartuska, ministry representative for energy security, told CTK.

He explained that in this respect, it was a natural step to establish an energy security department concentrating experts on energy and interconnecting the state authorities, at least until the insecurity caused by the Russian war against Ukraine ends.

Chamber passes sanction bill against foreigners
680 字
2022 年 10 月 14 日 12:52 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Oct 14 (CTK) - The Chamber of Deputies today passed a sanction bill against foreigners and foreign companies that committed an unlawful act, under which the Czech state can impose a ban on entry and stay on them or freeze their property.

The law will also make it possible to impose restrictions on organisations and regimes that are violating human rights and use terrorist methods and cyber attacks.

The bill, under which other penalties than those on the EU sanction list can be used, will now be passed on to the Senate, the upper house of Czech parliament.

In the Chamber of Deputies, it was supported by 112 out of 130 present MPs, none of them voted against it. The opposition Freedom and Democracy (SPD) MPs abstained from the vote along with Milan Brazdil and Tatana Mala from senior opposition ANO.

„I consider this the result of confident foreign policy. I am glad that the bill won broad support and I hope it will become a full-fledged part of the foreign policy after it is dealt with in the Senate and passes through the Prague Castle,“ Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) told journalists.

The Prague Castle is the seat of the Presidential Office.

The bill says that the government will decide whether to put someone on the sanction list based on the Foreign Ministry's suggestion. Objections to the listing will also be sent to the ministry, and the government will decide on them. The people on the list can defend themselves at court, the Metropolitan Court in Prague will be the court of first instance.

The lower house legal and constitutional committee recommended that the lower house shorten the period the government has for reviewing the decision to put someone on a sanction list by one third to 30 days. The lower house agreed with this today.

It also specified the list of regulations based on which a certain act can be considered punishable in accordance with the sanction law.

Karel Haas (Civic Democrats, ODS) and Helena Valkova's (ANO) adjustments, praised by Lipavsky, are supposed to secure that foreigners and foreign companies will be put on the list justly.

In its policy statement, PM Petr FIala's (ODS) cabinet assumed that the Magnitsky Act, which is to improve the enforcement of human rights protection, would be passed by the end of next year.

The work on the bill was sped up because of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. In the EU, France, the Netherlands, Latvia and Estonia have similar laws.

Lipavsky said Czechia will rely on sanction regimes based on EU legislation. Talks on sanction measures on the European level will be a priority, he said. "If we do not succeed in the EU, we may adopt measures of our won. At the same time, we need to wait for the EU if we recognise that the interest is strong enough," he said.

He noted that a new section for sanction policies will be working at his ministry as of January.

The Magnitsky Act is to improve the enforcement of human rights protection.

The US Congress approved the Magnitsky Act under then president Barack Obama who signed it in December 2012. It bans the Russian representatives involved in human rights infringement and those who might have contributed to Magnitsky's death from entering the country.

The act bears the name of Russian tax lawyer Sergei Magnitsky who died in a Moscow prison in 2009. He was arrested and charged with committing tax fraud in 2008 after having investigated an extensive fraud involving Russian police and judicial officials.

Magnitsky was hired in Russia by Bill Browder, a prominent British-American financier working extensively in Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Browder, who was sentenced to nine years in absentia in Moscow for tax evasion in 2013, published the case and lobbied among American officials to pass a legislation sanctioning Russian individuals involved in corruption. He led the campaign targeting those involved in Magnitsky's death.

Czech parliament approves Czech Magnitsky Act
Aneta Zachová
231 字
2022 年 10 月 17 日 06:54 GMT
EurActiv.com
EURACOM
英文
Copyright 2022. EurActiv.com All Rights Reserved.
Czech lawmakers approved the Magnitsky Act on Friday, allowing the Czech government to impose sanctions on foreign entities violating human rights, supporting terrorism, or committing cyber crimes.

The Czech government planned to adopt the Magnitsky Act by the end of next year, but the preparation of the draft was accelerated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

“It will make the Czech Republic the first Central European country to have its instrument to sanction serious human rights violations,” Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavský said.

Among EU countries, France, the Netherlands, Latvia and Estonia have similar laws. The law sets out the conditions for the inclusion of entities on the national sanctions list and the procedure for preparing proposals for the inclusion of entities on the EU sanctions list at the Czech initiative.

According to the proposal, the inclusion on the sanctions list will be decided by the Government on the proposal of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. For example, the state will be able to prevent sanctioned individuals from entering and staying in the country or freezing their assets.

Czech law was inspired by the US Magnitsky Act, named after a Ukrainian-born lawyer and tax advisor who died in Russian state custody in 2009 after he reported on corruption.

The law now needs to be approved by the Senate.

(Aneta Zachová | EURACTIV.cz)

Luxembourg, Oct 17 (CTK correspondent) - Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky supported the punishment of Iran for delivering drones to Russia at a meeting of foreign ministers of the EU countries today.

"Iran joined forces with the Russian Federation in the war against Ukraine. It started supplying considerable amount of military equipment, at present we see for example drone attacks," Lipavsky said.

He said the EU must do its utmost so that Russia does not have enough means to wage war.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba, who joined the meeting online from an air-raid shelter, said the unmanned aerial vehicles that attack Ukrainian towns were delivered by Iran. The secret services of the United States and some other EU countries are also convinced about this.

However, EU diplomacy chief Josep Borrell said some EU countries demand the presentation of clear evidence of Iran's deliveries. He said the evidence is being gathered.

The punishment of Iran for the military deliveries was today supported also by the representatives of the governments of Poland and the Baltic states.

The EU today imposed sanctions on 11 Iranian officials and four institutions including the morality police for their contribution to the death of 22-year-old Iranian woman Mahsa Amini and for the subsequent brutal suppression of protests. Amini was supposedly detained over her hijab having been too loose. The police said Amini died of heart attack, but her family and other sources said she died due to the police brutality.

The EU foreign ministers today unanimously agreed to sanction Iran's morality police.

"The Iranian regime brutally suppresses the rights of women and the inhabitants are logically losing patience," Lipavsky said after the meeting in Luxembourg.

So far, 97 officials and eight entities have been punished by the EU for the violation of human rights in Iran. The EU freezes the property of the punished persons and bans them from entering EU territory.

Czechs warn ‘colonial’ Russia will be a threat even if Putin falls
Catherine Philp, Diplomatic Correspondent
648 字
2022 年 11 月 17 日 14:20 GMT
thetimes.co.uk
TIMEUK
英文
© Times Newspapers Limited 2022
Russia is the “last imperialistic power in the world” and is unlikely to change even if Vladimir Putin were to go, the Czech foreign minister warned, urging the West to stay the course in countering Moscow’s aggression.

In an interview with The Times, Jan Lipavsky warned against the fantasy that the war in Ukraine would end if Putin lost power or that Russia’s ambitions would shrink.

“We have to understand that Russia is the last colonial and imperialistic power in the world,” he told the Times. “The idea of imperial Russia, it’s not only connected to one man or to elites in Moscow, but to the whole concept on which the Russian state is now built upon.”

•

Liberators find dozens of tortured bodies in Kherson[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/ukrainians-find-dozens-of-tortured-bodies-in-kherson-7j6fj87z3]

Eastern Europe’s experience of Moscow’s imperialistic behaviour has made its countries among the most outspoken over Russia’s invasion of

Ukraine[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/topic/ukraine?page=1]

.

“I think it is natural that there are some historical memory connected to Russian imperialism and colonialism,” Lipavsky, 37, the youngest ever Czech foreign minister, said. “It easily and immediately triggers your reaction to the same behaviour of the Moscow leadership in another country.”

It is that experience, he says, that should make western Europe heed the east’s warnings about the challenge

Russia[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/topic/russia?page=1]

will continue to pose even if Putin falls. Russia’s poor management of the invasion has reopened questions about Putin’s future, though much of the harshest criticism comes from right-wing nationalists who believe Putin has simply not gone far enough.

“I don’t want to predict what will be the future of the current Russian leadership. That’s not my role to ever say, it’s for Russian people to have a say in it,” Lipavsky said. “But [while] we have this Russian leadership, we need to be ready to contain it from Europe.

“They will think in the scheme of 19th century, they will think in a scheme of grabbing territory by brute force, which is trying to destroy the charter of UN and the very basic principles, which are carved in stone in the document after the Second World War, that the borders won’t be changed by force.”

The Czech Republic currently holds the EU council presidency, which it has used to promote a message of unity over the European response to Ukraine. Lipavsky described Russia’s invasion on February 24 as “the day when the geopolitical Europe was born again”.

He said: “We have aid sanction packages in the EU. We have many decisions on sanctions down from the platform of the G7, we have a clear and unanimous voice from Nato. The UK and the Czech Republic are strong allies and I would like to underline this, these alliances are very, very important. So the common reaction of the West is strong.

“Yes, we have a lot of ongoing debates. In Europe we have certain differences. We have different accents. But at the end of the day, they are united in protection of our civilisation.”

He described the Czech Republic as in a “constant battle” with Russian influence campaigns against the Czech population trying to weaken its relations with western Europe. “It’s a never ending story of explaining why we do what we do and to explain to the public our actions. And definitely Russian trolls are misusing our weaknesses. The right answer is resilience.”

Europe so far has demonstrated that, he argues. “Putin has been absolutely unsuccessful in dividing the West. He started one year ago when he manipulated the energy market with gas prices and created and helped to create inflation in Europe.

“Putin was unsuccessful when he started the war and united the West. And Putin is unsuccessful now with his hybrid warfare against Europe.”

West ‘should not dictate’ peace terms to Ukraine, says Czech foreign minister
Dan Sabbagh Defence and security editor
706 字
2022 年 11 月 17 日 19:28 GMT
The Guardian
GRDN
英文
© Copyright 2022. The Guardian. All rights reserved.
Jan Lipavský says western backers should recognise Ukraine is fighting against Russia to protect all EuropeRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updates

Western backers of Ukraine “should not dictate” peace terms to Kyiv and recognise that the country is in effect fighting against Russia to protect all of Europe, the Czech foreign minister has said on a trip to London.

Jan Lipavský, whose country holds the EU presidency, also blamed Russia for what appears to be a stray air defence missile landing in Poland[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/nov/15/stray-russian-missiles-feared-landed-poland-ukraine] on Tuesday, because it had attacked Ukraine with “more than 100 rockets”.

“We shouldn’t be in a position where we dictate to Ukraine with other conditions for peace, if they are fighting for their own survival,” Lipavský said, when asked if it was reasonable for Ukraine to demand a restoration of the pre-2014 borders.

At stake, the minister added, were the UN principles of territorial integrity and the international rules-based order. “Putin wants to destroy the principle that the borders of states are not changed by brute force,” he argued.

Lipavský’s comments come as some US figures, led by Gen Mark Milley, the head of the country’s armed forces, have voiced concern that the fighting in the war is likely to descend into a stalemate over the winter and that Kyiv should consider reopening diplomatic discussions with Russia.

But many in Europe have pushed back at the suggestion, believing any halt to the conflict would favour Russia, which still occupies large parts of Ukraine’s territory. Lipavský said countries across the continent were benefiting from providing Ukraine with ongoing military, financial and humanitarian aid.

“Ukrainians made the clear choice they didn’t want to be part of Moscow’s empire,” Lipavský said. It was necessary for the west to help protect Ukraine over the long haul, he added, because their battle against their neighbour “is also protecting us”.

Prague has been the site of pro- and anti-government demonstrations in the past few weeks amid rising prices that critics of the country’s centre-right government want to pin on the government’s pro-Ukraine policy.

Lipavský, though, said he was confident that the Czech Republic would not relent in its support of Kyiv and referenced its mid 20th-century history of being dominated by Nazi Germany and then the Soviet Union.

“Freedom is not for free,” the minister said, adding that his country had suffered heavily in the 50 years before the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. “So maybe this winter will be harsher. But the price we would pay for not being free? It’s much, much, much, much higher.”

The foreign minister said it was “quite easy to answer who’s to blame” for the deaths of two Poles on Tuesday after a stray missile – believed to be from a Ukrainian S-300 air defence system – landed on a farm about four miles from the border.

“More than 100 Russian rockets on Tuesday were flying towards Ukraine with one clear aim: to destroy and cripple Ukrainian energy infrastructure, to kill people, to sow terror,” he said, arguing that Kyiv had a right to defend itself against the assault.

The Czech minister said the EU was “working on a ninth round” of economic sanctions directed against Russia, but would offer no specifics of what they could contain, reflecting wrangling among the bloc’s members about what they can agree on to target and worries about the cost of getting Hungary to sign up.

Hungary, led by prime minister Viktor Orbán, the EU leader most sympathetic to Russia, has increasingly raised questions about additional sanctions and has run a public campaign describing them as bombs that punish Europeans financially. When asked if Hungary was a problem, Lipavský paused and tactfully described the country as “a member of the EU and Nato”.

The foreign minister was in the UK to collect a Magnitsky human rights award for his part in the Czech Republic passing a law last month allowing the country to sanction Russia or other foreign entities violating human rights, supporting terrorism, or committing cybercrimes.

Sport
A player can make himself an icon with one moment of bravery
AIDAN FITZMAURICE
1014 字
2022 年 11 月 19 日
Irish Independent
IINM
1; National
11
英文
(c) 2022 Independent Newspapers Ireland Ltd
A

S JAMES McCLEAN usually discovers around this time of the year, taking a stance on a point of principle can leave a footballer exposed and alone. The fact that McClean continues to refuse to wear a poppy on his shirt every November, despite the anger and anguish that lands on his shoulders as he insists he's right, is admirable.

Staying silent would make life easier and McClean knows that the flak he will get for his stance will follow him around long after he's retired from playing.

But the principled Derryman does not want that easy life if it means surrendering his beliefs.

Football over the next month will show us how much footballers care about what goes on beyond the pitch, and what they are willing to do about it.

Certain teams have already raised their voices, as a collective, about how they feel about the host nation and its treatment of migrant workers, the LGBTQ+ community and females.

There are no 'out' gay players at this World Cup but it's inconceivable to believe that not one squad member has a relative or close friend who is gay.

So spending a month in a country where homosexuality is illegal has to be uncomfortable for someone with a sibling or friend who happens to be gay.

We have seen figures within football lose their dedication to causes once the dollar signs are flashed. Hence David Beckham's fall from grace from being an icon of the LGBTQ+ community who was left with "a sick feeling in your mouth" after Qatar won the World Cup hosting rights to a paid emissary of the Qataris.

Others have simply lost a once-powerful voice. The 1997-era Robbie Fowler pulled up his Liverpool jersey to show off a t-shirt supporting a dockers' strike in his home city, aware he would be fined by UEFA. The 2022 version of Robbie Fowler comes to Dublin earlier this month on a paid gig for a beer company but insists he will only do interviews if he's not asked about three topics, one of which is Qatar.

When the Irish Independent's man on site asks Fowler about England captain Harry Kane wearing a rainbow armband in Qatar as a gesture of solidarity to the LGBTQ+ community, the PR handler stepped in to stop the conversation. Maybe Fowler only cares about the poorly treated working class if they are English.

The stance by the Danish and Australian squads, and pledges by captains like Kane to wear a rainbow armband, are welcome, but is that it? With the world watching, will any player break away and become their own James McClean, take a stand on an issue no matter the fallout?

It's not an easy thing to ask as breaking the law in a country like Qatar could have serious consequences, even for a famous athlete.

Poland were refusing to play Russia even if it meant forfeiting the World Cup

US basketball player Brittney Griner had a relatively high profile but that did not prevent her from her bruising encounter with Russia's judicial system, as she now serves a nine-year sentence in a Russian penal colony, over a trumped-up drug-possession charge.

If Qatar's royal family can ban the sale of alcohol at all stadiums overnight, causing massive losses for a world brand like Budweiser, would the third-choice goalkeeper from Australia really be confident he'd avoid any sanction from local police by unfurling a rainbow flag?

This World Cup had already shown the potential for player power and illustrated the vast gulf between heartless blazers like Putinworshipper

Gianni Infantino and footballers with a conscience.

To recap what happened for the qualifiers: Poland were due to play Russia in Moscow in a World Cup play-off semi-final last March, with either Sweden or the Czech Republic facing the winners of that tie.

Right after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, a pathetically weak-minded FIFA wanted the Russia-Poland game to go ahead, content to leave Russia still in with a chance to make it to the World Cup finals.

Their recognition that Russia had invaded a neighbour was to suggest moving the game away from Moscow, and downgrade Russia's status as a team by asking them to not use their flag, anthem and play under a makey-up name. Probably the "most FIFA" thing that FIFA have done in a decade.

What happened next was remarkable and admirable. The FAs of Poland, Sweden and Czech Republic all said they would refuse to play Russia, even if it meant missing out on the World Cup.

But the origin of Poland's stance came from their players. Goalkeeper Wojcheich Szczesny had a personal insight: his wife is Ukrainian so he knew better than most.

"I refuse to play against players who choose to represent the values and principles of Russia!

"I refuse to stand on the pitch, wearing the colours of my country and listen to the national anthem of Russia," the 'keeper said in a social media post.

Kane a rainbow captain's armband Pride June

When captain Robert Lewandowski backed Szczesny's stance it was game over as that position, refusing to play Russia even if it meant forfeiting the World Cup, became the FA's position.

FIFA may have eventually kicked Russia out of the competition but Szczesny being so vocal so early forced everyone's hand.

Not everyone is as brave, and not everyone is as invested as Szczesny was due to his family link. James

McClean is surely not the only Irish footballer in England who feels uncomfortable wearing a poppy but he's the only one willing to take a stand on it as others go with the flow.

The next month offers dozens of footballers an opportunity: to break away and become and McClean, or stay quiet, plead ignorance and take the money like Fowler.

Independent Newspapers Ireland Limited

Czech premier to attend V4 meeting after parliamentary leaders boycott it
491 字
2022 年 11 月 21 日 06:51 GMT
bne IntelliNews
BNEINT
英文
© 2022. bne IntelliNews. All Rights reserved.
Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala will attend the Visegrad Group (V4) meeting on November 24 hosted by Slovakia in its second largest city in Kosice not far from the Ukrainian border. The decision comes after Parliamentary Speaker Marketa Pekarova Adamova and Czech Senate President Milos Vystrcil boycotted meeting their Hungarian counterparts over the Hungarian stance towards Ukraine and its energy policies.

“Hungarians bilaterally negotiate with Russia over supplies of energy commodities,” Vystrcil told local media, adding that this prevents a “united stance of EU countries and implementation of our goals in this energy crisis” and that the boycott is a “rational and sober way to express disagreement” on the V4 level. The war in Ukraine, the energy crisis and migration are key agenda topics in Kosice.

Pekarova Adamova called Hungary a “trojan horse of Russia” in line with comments of other Czech representatives such as the lower house's vice-speaker Olga Richterova from last week. “It is always Hungarians who agree with the sanction packages last” […], “blackmailing further sanctions, and they are exploiting the war themes domestically against the EU,” Pekarova Adamova said.

Fiala said he wants to discuss “common approach and common rules” on supporting the economy during the energy crisis, pointing to the German €200mn package, which “causes concern among EU member states”. In an interveiw for Czech newsite Seznam Zpravy, Fiala said that after a dialogue “Hungary supported all the key decisions during EU negotiations".

Prior to the war Fiala and Vystrcil’s rightwing ODS avoided criticism of Fidesz and maintained friendly ties with it. ODS MEP Jan Zahradil, who represents the strong conservative and eurosceptic wing within the party, called on the EU to accept Hungarian strongmanViktor Orban after Fidesz’s flawed general election victory in April. Another MEP Alexandr Vondra, a former liberal dissident who has moved to the right, also defends Fidesz rule in Hungary.

One of Fidesz’s 1988 co-founders and the current Speaker of the National Assembly Laszlo Kover issued a press statement in which he regretted the V4 house speakers' meeting was postponed as a result of the Czech boycott.

“The remarks of the speakers of the Czech Parliament concerning our country are untrue and disrespectful,” Kover wrote, highlighting that these “do not correspond to the facts and they call into question the right of the Hungarian government to shape its policy according to the interest of the Hungarian nation”.

Czechia holds the EU’s rotating presidency and its Europan Affairs Minister Mikulas Bek chairs EU discussions over the breaches of rule of law, civil liberties, and democracy in Hungary. Last week Bek criticised Hungary for obstructing the EU’s efforts to raise cash on financial markets for a loan to Ukraine, warning it could alienate EU officials in the upcoming response to Hungary’s proposals to unlock the rule of law conditionality to gain access to EU funds.

Czech premier to attend V4 meeting despite boycott of Hungary by parliamentary leaders

Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala will attend the Visegrad Group (V4) meeting on November 24 hosted by Slovakia, even though Parliamentary Speaker Marketa Pekarova Adamova and Senate President Milos Vystrcil boycotted meeting their Hungarian counterparts over Budapest's stance towards Ukraine and its energy policies. The meeting is being held in Slovakia's second largest city in Kosice, not far from the Ukrainian border

Hungary is becoming increasingly isolated in the EU and among its regional allies, the V4 countries, for its more pro-Russian position in Moscow's war against Ukraine and for blocking EU initiatives to punish Moscow for its aggression and help Ukraine. These differences have rendered the regional group moribund since Russia's invasion.

But there are differing views within the V4, the Czech coalition government and even within the rightwing Czech Civic Democrats on how tough a stance to take towards Viktor Orban's radical rightwing regime.

“Hungarians bilaterally negotiate with Russia over supplies of energy commodities,” Vystrcil told local media, adding that this prevents a “united stance of EU countries and implementation of our goals in this energy crisis” and that the boycott is a “rational and sober way to express disagreement” on the V4 level. The war in Ukraine, the energy crisis and migration are key agenda topics in Kosice.

Pekarova Adamova called Hungary a “trojan horse of Russia” in line with comments of other Czech representatives such as the lower house's vice-speaker Olga Richterova from last week. “It is always Hungarians who agree with the sanction packages last” […], “blackmailing further sanctions, and they are exploiting the war themes domestically against the EU,” Pekarova Adamova said.

Fiala said he wants to discuss “common approach and common rules” on supporting the economy during the energy crisis, pointing to the German €200mn package, which “causes concern among EU member states”. In an interveiw for Czech newsite Seznam Zpravy, Fiala said that after a dialogue “Hungary supported all the key decisions during EU negotiations".

Prior to the war Fiala and Vystrcil’s rightwing ODS avoided criticism of Fidesz and maintained friendly ties with it. ODS MEP Jan Zahradil, who represents the strong conservative and eurosceptic wing within the party, called on the EU to accept Hungarian strongmanViktor Orban after Fidesz’s flawed general election victory in April. Another MEP Alexandr Vondra, a former liberal dissident who has moved to the right, also defends Fidesz rule in Hungary.

One of Fidesz’s 1988 co-founders and the current Speaker of the National Assembly Laszlo Kover issued a press statement in which he regretted the V4 house speakers' meeting was postponed as a result of the Czech boycott.

“The remarks of the speakers of the Czech Parliament concerning our country are untrue and disrespectful,” Kover wrote, highlighting that these “do not correspond to the facts and they call into question the right of the Hungarian government to shape its policy according to the interest of the Hungarian nation”.

Czechia holds the EU’s rotating presidency and its Europan Affairs Minister Mikulas Bek chairs EU discussions over the breaches of rule of law, civil liberties, and democracy in Hungary. Last week Bek criticised Hungary for obstructing the EU’s efforts to raise cash on financial markets for a loan to Ukraine, warning it could alienate EU officials in the upcoming response to Hungary’s proposals to unlock the rule of law conditionality to gain access to EU funds.

Poland and Slovakia have also strongly criticised Hungary's stance towards Russia and Ukraine. In an interview published on November 9, Slovak Foreign Minister Rastislav Kacer (a former Slovak ambassador to Hungary) told the Slovak website Napunk [https://napunk.dennikn.sk/hu/3097730/rastislav-kacer-kulugyminiszter-orbanek-ervei-a-szankciokrol-mintha-a-kreml-kezikonyvebol-szarmaznanak/?utm_source=Insight+Hungary&utm_campaign=690d815a00-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2022_11_17_06_09&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_-690d815a00-%5BLIST_EMAIL_ID%5D](published in Hungarian) that Hungary's arguments against sanctions "seem to come from the Kremlin playbook".

"The arguments we hear from the Hungarian government are often the same as those used by the Kremlin's propaganda in its information war. I do not understand. These sanctions are in no way more damaging to Europe. Some even say they are helping Russia – if that were true, Russia wouldn't be rebelling against them. Hungary is alone in the European Union with this view and is completely isolated from its other Western allies"

U.S. Presses Allies To Tighten Up Russia Sanctions
By Ian Talley
1036 字
2022 年 11 月 22 日
The Wall Street Journal
J
A1
英文
Copyright 2022 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
WASHINGTON -- U.S. officials are jetting around the globe in a quiet diplomatic push to get Russia's major trading partners to enforce sanctions and trade controls, as exports to the country pick up after diving in the weeks following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.

The U.S. and its allies claimed early successes in their international pressure campaign, which disrupted Russia's military supply chains and pitched its economy into a steep contraction.

But so-called sanctions leakage -- in which weak enforcement enables banned finance and trade to flow -- is undermining the campaign, aiding Russia's economy and potentially prolonging the war, according to senior Western officials.

"We want to avoid circumvention, both within Europe and then with third countries," European Commission financial-services commissioner Mairead McGuinness, whose office oversees European Union sanctions policy, said in an interview. "The longer we have any leakage . . . the more difficult it is to see things coming to a conclusion."

Ms. McGuinness's office is sifting through European customs data to root out evasion, she said.

To tighten the finance and trade cordon established by Western countries, the U.S. is sending senior officials from major cabinet agencies to foreign capitals. Their mission: to share intelligence on sanctions evasion networks, quietly threaten reluctant authorities and firms with punitive action, and gather information on groups suspected of ferrying supplies into Russia, according to administration officials.

Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen pressed the case with counterparts at the Group of 20 industrialized and developing nations in Bali, Indonesia, last week. Earlier this month, Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo went to Brussels, London and Paris. Elizabeth Rosenberg, assistant secretary for terror finance and financial crimes, was recently in Japan on the same mission.

Lower-level officials from the Treasury, Commerce and State departments are also jetting around the globe.

"There are public reports that Russian money laundering is active in the Arab world," Ms. Rosenberg told a Union of Arab Banks conference late last month, using unusually pointed language that U.S. officials said was intended as a warning. "This is something we all have a vested interest in preventing, investigating and eliminating."

Trade data through the second quarter show exports to Russia from many of the world's largest economies collapsed by more than 50% in the wake of the sanctions imposed in late February. But exports are recovering from many of those countries, including the U.S.'s traditional allies, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of trade data.

Exports from allies South Korea and Japan remain below presanction levels but have recovered nearly a third of their initial losses, according to the Journal's analysis.

The EU has continued to expand the total share of exports banned under the Russia sanctions, but it has also erased some of its initial trade declines.

Western officials and some senior compliance officers are concerned that banks in Austria, the Czech Republic and Switzerland -- a non-European Union member that has adopted the EU sanctions -- are taking a relaxed view of sanctions enforcement.

While most companies and banks are avoiding transactions that could potentially breach the sanctions, "some industry players see this as an opportunity," said George Voloshin, a Russia sanctions investigator at the Association of Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialists. "For example, they are very relaxed when working with Russian government officials."

Swiss financial authorities in April said the country froze about $8 billion in Russian assets, but by May said that they had released about $3 billion of those assets. Industry analysts estimate the sum of Russian oligarchs' assets held in Switzerland to be much higher.

Antje Baertschi, spokeswoman for Switzerland's State Secretariat for Economic Affairs, said the level of assets frozen by the government was "high by international standards as well as in comparison to other sanctions regimes."

"We are completely unaware of any criticism," Ms. Baertschi said.

Austria's Raiffeisen Bank International said in March that it would review its exposure to Russia, a source of significant business, including possibly exiting the country. Months later, it said in its third-quarter report that it was still assessing its strategic options in the country. By contrast, most Western banks immediately restricted financial dealings with Russia after the February invasion.

"RBI Group is, of course, complying with all applicable sanctions," said Ingrid Ditz, Raiffeisen Bank spokeswoman. She said the bank had reduced its loans to customers in Russia by 25% in rubles since the beginning of the year and limited new lending.

Exports to Russia from China -- which hasn't backed the Western pressure campaign -- are now larger than they were when sanctions were imposed. U.S. officials are concerned that China will provide the financing and goods critical to Russia's war effort and economy. Beijing has said it won't comply with Western sanctions it says are illegal.

"Sino-Russian relations are rock-solid," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian said at a regular news briefing this month.

Exports to Russia from Turkey -- a North Atlantic Treaty Organization member that has supplied Kyiv with armed drones and played a key role in diplomatic talks over Ukrainian grain exports -- were up about 25% at the end of the second quarter from before the sanctions. Recent data show that exports from Turkey to Russia have picked up further since.

Nureddin Nebati, the country's finance minister, said his nation isn't undermining the pressure campaign. "We are continuing our trade with Russia in areas that are not subject to any sanction," he told the Journal in an interview.

Ankara said it had halted plans in its banking sector to connect Turkey's financial industry to Russia's payments system, which would have provided Moscow with an important link to the global financial system. Most of Russia's banking system has been sanctioned.

"It is a global effort," Brian Nelson, undersecretary for terrorism and financial intelligence, said in an interview. That means, "going after sanctions evasion, targeting our efforts to have an impact on the battlefield, and going after those who continue to allow President [Vladimir] Putin to project power."

---

Andrew Duehren and Caitlin Ostroff contributed to this article.

Russia war in Ukraine is lesson in combined attacks - Czech PM
451 字
2022 年 11 月 22 日 11:58 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Nov 22 (CTK) - The Russian aggression in Ukraine is a lesson in combined conventional and hybrid attacks and Czechia must use this experience when it will be updating its strategic documents next year, Prime Minister Petr Fiala (Civic Democrats, ODS) said at a gathering of the Czech military command today.

Fiala said the recent fall of missiles in Polish territory showed that there is always a risk of escalation of the conflict.

He said Russia systematically undermined international order, violated unwritten rules of international relations and concrete agreements many times in the last ten years.

"The current aggression against Ukraine that has been lasting for nine months, this is something absolutely extraordinary," Fiala said.

He said the Czech position remains clear from the very beginning - it is necessary to help Ukraine and contribute to that the Russian aggression ends as soon as possible. "This is in our interest to weaken the Russian threat against Europe," he said.

Fiala thanked the military for managing to quickly arrange arms and ammunition deliveries to Ukraine. "First of all thanks to you we have become one of the most important supporters of Ukraine in Europe," he said.

He also mentioned the training of Ukrainian soldiers in Czechia that his government approved last week. Up to 4,000 Ukrainian soldiers will undergo training on Czech territory by the end of next year, 800 of them this year already.

The Russian war in Ukraine is a hard lesson, he said. "It turns out that waging a war on the ground, in the air and on sea is not something from the past as somebody expected. The war did not move but it rather extended," Fiala said.

Conventional and hybrid fighting is parallel, through economic pressure and espionage, he said.

Czechia must be alert all the time because it faces an unprecedented combination of threats, he added, mentioning risks of attacks against critical infrastructure, Russian hybrid attacks and propaganda but also misuse of migration and destabilisation of the energy market.

The war in Ukraine led to a stronger unity of Western countries and the readiness of international institutions for action, Fiala said. "Unlike previous Russian provocations, the Western democracies did not issue just diplomatic notes and symbolical sanctions this time," he said.

The primary framework of Czech security is NATO, Fiala said. He also appreciated that the European Union was able to quickly agree on sanction packages imposed on Russia.

Fiala repeatedly said the government is ready to spend 2 percent of GDP on defence as of 2024. He thanked Defence Minister Jana Cernochova (ODS) for her effort to speed up military purchases.

Senate passes bill on sanctions over foreigners' unlawful acts
644 字
2022 年 12 月 1 日 12:00 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Dec 1 (CTK) - The Senate, the upper house of Czech parliament, as expected passed today the bill on national sanctions targeting foreign firms and individuals committing serious unlawful acts, which will enable the state to deny their Czech entry or stay or freeze their property, among others.

The piece of legislation, related to the Russian aggression against Ukraine, will also make it possible to impose restrictions on organisations and regimes that are violating human rights and use terrorist methods and cyber attacks.

The bill was supported by 53 out of the 65 senators present.

The Chamber of Deputies, the lower house, passed it in mid-October. Now it will be sent to President Milos Zeman to sign it into law.

Only senator Jana Zwyrtek Hamplova (fro Independents) criticised the legislation saying it was unclear.

Under the bill, that the government will decide whether to put someone on the sanction list based on the Foreign Ministry's suggestion. Objections to the listing will also be sent to the ministry, and the government will decide on them. The people on the list can defend themselves in court, the Metropolitan Court in Prague will be the court of the first instance.

The new legislation will enable to apply even other sanctions than those included on the EU sanction list.

The lower house met its legal and constitutional committee recommendation and shortened the period the government had for reviewing the decision to put someone on a sanction list by one third to 30 days. It also specified the list of regulations based on which a certain act can be considered punishable in accordance with the sanction law.

In its policy statement from early 2022, the government of Petr Fiala's (Civic Democrats, ODS) outlined the introduction of the law, known as the Magnitsky Act, aimed to improve the enforcement of human rights protection until the end of 2023. The drafting of the bill accelerated in reaction to the February 2022 start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Out of the EU states, similar laws are in force in France, the Netherlands, Latvia and Estonia.

The law defines the conditions for subjects to be put on the national list of sanctions, and the steps to prepare Czech proposals for subjects' EU listing.

Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) previously said Czechia would lean on the sanction regimes stemming from the EU law. Negotiations about sanctions on the EU level will be the priority, he added.

"If we do not succeed in the EU, we can adopt our own measures. At the same time, it is true that we need not wait for the EU if we find out that the interest [in listing a subject] is strong enough," Lipavsky said earlier.

He mentioned the planned establishment of a new department for sanction policies at the Foreign Ministry as of the beginning of next year.

The US Congress approved the Magnitsky Act under then president Barack Obama who signed it in December 2012. It bans the Russian representatives involved in human rights infringement and those who might have contributed to Magnitsky's death from entering the country.

The act bears the name of Russian tax lawyer Sergei Magnitsky who died in a Moscow prison in 2009. He was arrested and charged with committing tax fraud in 2008 after having investigated an extensive fraud involving Russian police and judicial officials.

Magnitsky was hired in Russia by Bill Browder, a prominent British-American financier working extensively in Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Browder, who was sentenced to nine years in absentia in Moscow for tax evasion in 2013, published the case and lobbied among American officials to pass a legislation sanctioning Russian individuals involved in corruption. He led the campaign targeting those involved in Magnitsky's death.

EU increasing help for Ukrainian media - Czech EU commissioner
457 字
2022 年 12 月 1 日 11:02 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Dec 1 (CTK) - The EU increased its financial aid to the independent Ukrainian media after the start of the Russian invasion and now the sum amounts to 23 million euros, Czech Vice President of the European Commission for Values and Transparency Vera Jourova told the media conference of the Eastern Partnership today.

Jourova is in charge of the media.

The EU is now coming to terms with three challenges regarding the Ukrainian media. These are the security of journalists, the help with economic survival and maintenance of independence of the media and the fight against disinformation spread by the Kremlin, Jourova said.

Before the war, the EU focused its help especially on the building of capacities and education, but now the support goes directly to the Ukrainian independent media. This entails financial help for the staff and operation, the measures in the sphere of cyber security and financing of protective equipment such as bullet-proof vests, she added.

It is of major importance to fight Russian disinformation, Jourova said.

Some of the anti-Russian sanction packages the EU passed included some media outlets, such as Russia Today or Sputnik. The prepared ninth package may include others, the tools of war propaganda of Russian President Vladimir Putin, she added.

Jourova mentioned the idea of founding the radio station Free Russia along the model of Radio Free Europe.

"I believe that many Russian citizens want to hear other reports than those they hear from the Kremlin," she said. This would be no propaganda, but information about the real situation back at home, she added.

The work of journalists in Ukraine is also important because they take part in the collection of evidence on war crimes, Jourova said.

The gathering of the evidence has started in 14 EU countries and the International Criminal Court has joined the effort.

Independent media is vital in general, Jourova said.

The freedom of speech is one of the foundations on which the EU is built. Independent and quality media is essential for the provision of trustworthy information so that citizens could make informed decisions and take part in the democratic process, she added.

The sound and free media environment is also important in the fight against organised disinformation campaigns, Jourova said."Such campaigns do not end at national borders. We are all interested in battling the hostile and harming disinformation campaigns in the EU and Eastern Partnership countries," she added.

The EU is supporting independent media environment in eastern countries with more than 30 million euros. It has set the ambitious target of supporting at least 120 independent media outlets and 2,000 journalists in the years to come, Jourova said.

EU increasing help for Ukrainian media - Czech EU commissioner
673 字

Prague, Dec 1 (CTK) - The EU increased its financial aid to the independent Ukrainian media after the start of the Russian invasion and now the sum amounts to 23 million euros, Czech Vice President of the European Commission for Values and Transparency Vera Jourova told the media conference of the Eastern Partnership today.

In the 1990s, the media space in Russia was relatively free, but now there is no space for freedom in it, there is just propaganda, Deputy Foreign Minister Jaroslav Kurfurst told the conference. He mentioned the editor-in-chief of the state-run television channel RT Margarita Simonyan and general director of the media holding Rossiya segodnya Dmitry Kiselyov.

"We are living in a special time, seeing the ascendancy of propagandists and technologies transforming the media landscape," he added.

This is nothing unknown. In the new dimension, the Czech Republic saw the lies and propaganda in the debates about the installation of the U.S. radar system in 2008, the migration wave in 2015 and now in the war in Ukraine, he added.

"We see a stream of hatred, militant imperialism," Kurfurst said. "Along with the ascendancy of propagandists, we can see attacks on independent journalists," he added.

Hundreds of them have had to leave not only Russia, but also Belarus and other countries.

Kurfurst said that while the Belarusian government did not cooperate with the Eastern Partnership, Belarusian journalists and civic society do. "This is proof that Belarus is part of this family. The Belarusian past is European and the Belarusian future will be again European," he added.

Czech EU presidency successful - top EU leaders
449 字
2022 年 12 月 16 日 06:47 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Brussels, Dec 16 (CTK special correspondent) - The Czech EU presidency was very active and committed and Prime Minister Petr Fiala and his team in Brussels and Prague deserve admiration, the president of the European Council, Charles Michel, told journalists after a one-day EU summit last night.

The president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said Europe had a debt towards the Czech Republic given its work in the past six months.

The Czech Republic took up the presidency amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine and at the start of the energy crisis, but still it managed to achieve compromises, to proceed in a collective way and to continue with the help to Kyiv, Fiala said, adding that the talks were not always simple, but thanks to a joint effort, they were always led to the finish.

At the end, Fiala thanked von der Leyen and Michel and wished successful presidency to Sweden that he will take it up on January 1.

"The whole presidency was a big challenge," Fiala said, replying to the question of what was the most difficult moment.

The talks with Hungary were delicate, he added.

Von der Leyen stressed "excellent cooperation" with the Czech Republic.

Michel said there had been no doubts that Czechs would be good.

Michel appreciated the way Czech representatives behaved during the presidency in order to protect the unity and credibility of the EU.

Von der Leyen said there had always been the idea that the Czech Republic was wonderful and the past six months had shown that it was even more so.

The summit was the last during the ending Czech EU presidency.

At the summit, the EU ambassadors agreed on a new package of sanctions against Russia. The EU countries also approved the compromise relating to Hungary's access to EU funds, financial support to Ukraine next year and introduction of minimal tax for multinational corporations.

Fiala, too, appreciated the results of the talks.

"This collective approach was confirmed by the approved package with macro-financial help to Ukraine and the ninth sanction package today," Fiala said.

"Perhaps we had to devote even more time, work and attention to the economic impact of the war, especially to the soaring prices of energy that have affected, in a varying way, but without exception, all citizens of membership countries," he added.

The last crucial step will be taken on Monday, at the session of energy ministers when the capping of gas prices is supposed to be passed, Fiala said.

He said a major shift had been achieved, though some compromises were still needed to reach the resulting consensus.

Russian hurdler stripped of 2012 Olympics gold for doping
281 字
2022 年 12 月 21 日 16:21 GMT
Associated Press Newswires
APRS
英文
(c) 2022. The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved.
MONACO (AP) — Russian 400-meter hurdler Natalya Antyukh will lose her gold medal from the 2012 London Games due to doping, putting American Lashinda Demus in position to be named the champion more than a decade after the race.

The Athletics Integrity Unit, which oversees doping cases in track and field, announced Wednesday that Antyukh had not appealed a penalty handed down two months ago that included the stripping of her results from July 2012 through June 2013. The AIU said the IOC could now “proceed with the reallocation of medals and the update of the IOC database.”

Zuzana Hejnová of the Czech Republic and Kaliese Spencer of Jamaica are in line to receive silver and bronze.

AIU said Antyukh, who had already been serving a four-year ban, received the added sanction of having the 2012 results stripped because of evidence that came from a database kept at the Moscow antidoping laboratory. Though AIU offered no specifics, data from that lab was used to corroborate findings in a number of cases that came out of Russia's state-sponsored doping scandal.

At the London Games, Antyukh finished in 52.70 seconds, lowering her personal best by .22 to beat Demus by .07.

Demus, who also won world championships in 2011, stopped competing in 2016.

In an email exchange with NBC Sports when the initial decision was released, Demus said “I’m not afraid to say that I then deserve the official title, medal, recognition, and missed compensation that goes along with it all.”

Czechia fulfilled EU-presiding country role consistently-experts
768 字
2022 年 12 月 21 日 13:12 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Brussels, Dec 21 (CTK correspondent) - Three political analysts in Brussels addressed by CTK have assessed the ending Czech EU presidency positively as successful and excellent, doing a lot of good work.

The experts appreciated the way of the Czech Republic moderating debates among the EU member states and highlighted the reached deals concerning support for Ukraine and the climate policy. At the same time, they expressed hope that Czechia would remain active on the EU scene even after transferring the presidency of the European Council to Sweden.

Excellent work on the whole, Georgina Wright, from the Paris-based Institute Montaigne, assessed the Czech EU presidency.

Wright, an analyst who previously worked in international institutions, including the European Commission, called the mapping of particular member countries' positions before Czechia assumed the presidency the key to its success. It worked hard and managed to make 27 countries reach consensus on significant drafts that would create the EU future, she summarised it.

The task of the country holding the six-month EU presidency is primarily to moderate the talks on legislative proposals and seek the path to achieve the needed support regardless of its own stance.

Commenting on the Czech performance in this respect, all the three analysts compared the developments in the past six months to the previous half a year of the French presidency.

It was clear that the French would rather push for the topics important to them, said Ziga Faktor, head of the Brussels-based section of the Europeum Czech institute. Czechs were playing the role of an unbiased negotiator much more and managed it very well even in the squabbles about the gas price capping, he noted.

Elizabeth Kuiper, from the European Policy Centre (EPC) think-tank, reminded that information had emerged during the previous EU presidency about delays in the EU processes as a consequence of the centralisation of the French bodies in Paris during the French presidency. She said she had heard that everything was running smoothly during the Czech presidency.

One of its main challenges in the summer was to preserve the EU unity in support of Ukraine and sanctions against Russia, waging war against this country since February. Hungary criticises the hard anti-Russian sanctions after some time, and blocked the new joint loan for Kyiv in the autumn. However, in the end, the EU unanimously approved another three sanction packages and financial aid to Ukraine worth 18 billion euros for next year under the Czech EU presidency.

Faktor said that in this case, the Czech EU presidency was "a blessing" for the European Union, referring to cultural bonds between the Czech Republic and Ukraine. It was a very hard task to maintain this consensus for further months in connection with the energy crisis and another possible migrant crisis, he pointed out, adding that Czechs passed the test excellently.

Wright and Kuiper also highlighted the approval of the crucial parts from the EU plan of 55 percent cutting the carbon dioxide emissions by the end of this decade.

There was slight scepticism at the beginning, as Czech EU presidency had a lot of work, but it became apparent that it had actually scored quite many successes when it came to stricter rules for the carbon dioxide emissions from cars and the review of the carbon credit trading system, Kuiper said.

The analysts did not raise many objections to the Czech EU presidency.

Wright only said the Czech government could improve communication to inform even the people who were not much observing the EU processes about its results.

Faktor said he regretted the Western Balkans issue being a bit dwarfed and with the misleading communication about the progress in the EU accession process of North Macedonia and Albania.

Kuiper mentioned the need to "increase ambitions" when it comes to the reform plans ensuing from the conference on the future of Europe. She added that in her opinion, many analysts as well as citizens were disappointed with the result.

Sweden will assume the Czech presidency in January, while the Czech Republic will get an opportunity to use the experience from its presidency to a more assertive performance on the EU level.

Wright said she hoped that the Czech Republic would continue being influential and loud in the issues it cared for in the future as well, since the Czech positions on some matters had not been very clear so far.

According to Faktor, the Czech Republic should keep actively participating in the EU policy and not neglect the bonds created during its presidency.

Czechia surprises as EU presiding country - presidency team head
610 字
2022 年 12 月 23 日 11:53 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Adds statements by Lipavsky in paras 3,11,12.

Brussels, Dec 23 (CTK correspondent) - Czechia did better job leading the EU than most diplomats had expected six months ago when the Czech presidency started, Czech Ambassador to the EU Edita Hrda has told CTK, adding that most diplomats appreciated Czechia having always sought unanimous agreement of all 26 states.

The presidency team has fulfilled the key task and kept the unity of EU member states in their stance on Ukraine and the pressure on Russia, she said.

Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) also told CTK that the Czech EU presidency has been successful.

Hrda said the disagreement on Romania and Bulgaria extending the Schengen area is a disappointment.

The Czech presidency managed to lead the EU to agreement on three sanction packages against Russia and to the passing of the financial aid for Ukraine worth the total of 18 billion euros, an equivalent to some 440 billion crowns. Hrda said the debates on these topics had been very difficult but they had also shown that the member states were determined to stand on Ukraine's side.

"There is huge will to continue. We all know that until we stop (Russian) President (Vladimir) Putin, we cannot slacken. There are some ideas what more would be worth doing and the preparation is continuous," Hrda said.

Unless the situation in Ukraine changes radically, it is almost certain that the EU will pass the tenth sanction package by late February, she noted.

Czechia was trying to achieve consensus in the debates concerning the war in Ukraine, which was one of the most appreciated characteristics of the Czech presidency, Hrda said.

Despite taking the comfort of all states into account and not wanting to push anyone into anything, as Hrda pointed out, Czechia managed to push through sanctions including the reduction of the import of Russian oil, although some states were against it at the beginning.

Czech negotiators also achieved consensus on Croatia extending the Schengen area, unlike Bulgaria and Romania which did not succeed due to the veto from Austria and the Netherlands.

Lipavsky also said Czechia failed to reach agreement on the entry of latter two countries to the Schengen system. "I see that especially in Romania it is rather hard for them to bear it. On the other hand, in such complicated affairs a lot of persistence is necessary," he said.

Lipavsky said the EU had crucial impact on the countries that are moving towards it. "There is no country that would be fully ready to enter the EU and would be only waiting for the door to be opened. These countries have each gone to various distances in this process, but nobody has fulfilled 100 percent of it," he said.

Prague earmarked much less money for the presidency than in 2009 when Czechia presided the EU for the first time. Some diplomats said it would be very difficult to lead the EU with a team of some 250 people, however, the Czech negotiators managed to find agreement on several key norms from the climatic package and the cap on gas prices. All this despite the fact that the debates often took place within a single day.

"I think the Brussels administrative is surprised with the quality of our clerks and diplomats," Hrda said, also praising some 60 interns.

The six months of the Czech presidency definitely put the Czech diplomacy on the map, she noted.

"It is only up to us how we will handle it," she concluded, saying the Czech presidency is the peak of her career.

Ukraine, energy crisis are Czech EU presidency's main challenges
1085 字
2022 年 12 月 29 日 09:54 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2022 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Dec 29 (CTK) - Selected data on the Czech Republic's six-month presidency of the European Union Council that ends on December 31:

- The Czech Republic assumed its second EU presidency in history on July 1, 2022. For the first time, Czechia presided over the EU in the first half of 2009. Like previously, it formed a "presidency trio" with France that the Czech Republic replaced in mid-2022, and Sweden that will take over the presidency on January 1, 2023.

- The biggest challenge of the Czech presidency was the continuing war in Ukraine, which Russia invaded on February 24, and the energy crisis deepened by the war. These two points were the crucial of the five priorities that the Czech presidency presented at its start. The others are strengthening of European defence capacities, cyber space security and resilience of European economy and democratic institutions.

- When it comes to the energy crisis, the EU countries agreed during the Czech EU presidency on reducing electricity consumption in peak time and on windfall tax or taxation of extraordinary profits of power plants and fossil fuel suppliers. After weeks of negotiations, they also reached consensus on the parametres of the emergency restriction of gas prices in the case of their exorbitant rise. The Czech EU presidency compromise proposal was eventually supported by a crushing majority of member states, including Germany that had long opposed it.

- One of the Czech presidency's main challenges in the summer was to preserve the EU unity in support of Ukraine and sanctions against Russia. Hungary criticised the hard anti-Russian sanctions after some time, and blocked the new joint loan for Kyiv in the autumn. However, in the end, the EU unanimously approved another three sanction packages and financial aid to Ukraine worth 18 billion euros for next year.

- The Czech presidency representatives have agreed with MEPs, among others, on a significant restriction on the sale of new combustion-engine cars by 2035, a reform of the carbon credit market and a binding goal for the carbon dioxide absorption in soil and forest management, by which they followed the core of the Green Deal for Europe. The reform of carbon credit market became a target of criticism by the opposition and some economic branches. The opposition mainly minds extending the market with carbon credits to apply to emissions from heating and road and sea transport as well. The steal producers' union called the EU decision to review the system of carbon credit trading as well as the emergency capping of gas prices beyond reality. However, the Czech Confederation of Industry and the Chamber of Commerce welcomed the EU agreement on capping gas prices at the stock exchange.

- According to the government, the Czech EU presidency scored success in unblocking the EU accession talks with Albania and North Macedonia, and giving the EU candidate status to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The EU also accepted Kosovo's bid for membership and launched talks about the EU accession of Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia. Besides, Czech negotiators managed to reach consensus on the admission of Croatia to the Schengen Area as of 2023. On the contrary, Bulgaria and Romania failed with their effort to enter Schengen due to the veto by Austria and the Netherlands.

- During the presidency, Czechs chaired 12 ministerial councils, 24 meetings of ambassadors and 31 talks on the final shape of bills with MEPs, the paper Financial Times has written. Besides, the EU energy ministers' special meetings took place eight times, which was the highest number of such events during an EU presidency, Czech Industry and Trade Minister Jozef Sikela said.

- The largest events in the Czech Republic under the aegis of its EU presidency were two summits. The first summit of the European Political Community (EPC), a broader format of European countries, in history was held in Prague on October 6, bringing together more than 40 supreme representatives of European countries, which was followed by the EU informal summit a day later.

- Not only the Czech government politicians, but also the EU top officials called the Czech EU presidency a success. European Council President Charles Michel said the Czech presidency was very active and committed. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said Europe owed Czechia a lot for its work in the past six months. European Commission (EC) Vice-President Frans Timmermans said the Czech presidency was one of the most successful presidencies in the past decades.

- The Czech presidency costs amounted to 1.835 billion crowns from the central budget, and further 0.5 billion from the chapters of particular sectors, so the total costs were 2.3 billion crowns. In 2007-2009, 3.75 billion crowns were earmarked for the preparation of the Czech EU presidency.

- The first Czech EU presidency in 2009 also dealt with the energy crisis. At the beginning of 2009, it had to tackle the dispute between Russia and Ukraine about gas supplies, the interruption of which affected European countries as well. Czechia convoked an extraordinary EU summit in Brussels for March 1, 2009 due to the financial crisis, and the EU regular summit also focused on the crisis. At the end of April 2009, then Albanian PM Sali Berisha officially submitted the country's request for EU membership in Prague. However, the presidency did not succeed in resuming the accession talks with Croatia that Slovenia blocked in December 2008 over the dispute about their joint border. Croatia joined the EU eventually in 2013. The Czech EU presidency then sent Montenegro's EU bid to further talks and registered a new applicant, Albania. No major progress was achieved in the EU accession talks with Turkey during the Czech presidency either.

- The EU-USA summit with then US president Barack Obama and the EU 27 countries' heads of state and government was staged during the first Czech EU presidency in early April 2009. In May, the summit of the EU and six post-Soviet republics took place in Prague, officially launching the Eastern Partnership project.

- Many analysts agree that the Czech Republic did not have a good starting position in 2009. It had to primarily tackle the economic crisis that for some time overshadowed even the EU immense problem with the Lisbon Treaty. Moreover, Czechs complicated the situation themselves when the lower house of parliament voted no confidence in the Czech government in March 2009 amid the EU presidency.

($1 = 22.796 crowns)

Czech Republic: Moneta stops processing payments to Russia, Belarus
M-Brain
127 字
2023 年 1 月 2 日
Esmerk CIS News
ESMKCIS
英文
Copyright 2023. M-Brain
Ceské Noviny, 02 Jan 2023, online:- Moneta Money Bank in the Czech Republic has stopped sending payments to Russia and Belarus from 1 January 2023. The bank has stated the reason as not being able to control if the payments are going to entities under sanctions unlike large Czech banks. Incoming payments from both countries will continue to be accepted by Moneta. Komercni Banka (KB), CSOB and Raiffeisenbank all continue to process payments to Russia and Belarus in line with current legislation and sanction policy, however, the payments are subject to strict control. UniCredit Bank does not support payments to Belarus and only processes payments to Russia in exceptional circumstances in line with all current policies.

Report: Czech Republic freezes VEB.RF's money in bankrupt firm
115 字
2023 年 1 月 17 日 05:20 GMT
Prime News
PRTASS
英文
© 2023. JSC PRIME. All rights reserved.
PRAGUE, Jan 17 (PRIME) -- The Financial Analytical Office of the Czech Republic has frozen U.S. $7.9 million of Russia's VEB.RF investment on accounts of bankrupt company Pilsen Steel, Czech Television reported late on Monday.

According to the channel, VEB.RF used to control Pilsen Steel that went bankrupt in 2019, after which its assets were frozen.

"In accordance with a new sanction law, the Foreign Ministry of the Czech Republic is preparing a so-called National Blacklist, cooperating with the police and intelligence. The information about the first entities to be listed could be announced soon," the channel reported.
