(CIANEWS) - The Škoda Group will deliver 10 more trains to the Estonian carrier Eesti Liinirongid (Elron) under an option to supply electric units. The first unit from this order is already in production, which now totals 16 vehicles. Production is taking place at the production plant in Ostrava. The contract with Elron totals more than CZK 3.5bn. The delivery of the first six trains is scheduled for completion by the end of 2024. The units are built on the RegioPanter platform (trains in the Czech Republic and Slovakia), which was also used in the design of trains to neighbouring Latvia.

GARBE will build the first 10,000 m2 for Taconova in its industrial park in České Budějovice. This will include 9,240 m2 of industrial space and 1,240 m2 of office space. The transaction was brokered by CBRE. Taconova will use the hall for warehousing and light manufacturing. The construction envisages the introduction of sustainable solutions. A green facade is planned and the park will be equipped with heat pumps and solar panels. Another 9,500 m2 will be delivered to the market by GARBE on a speculative basis.

AMiT, a manufacturer of control systems for industrial automation and electronics for rolling stock and public transport, plans to spend tens of millions of crowns on foreign projects and the development of new technologies in the coming years. This is expected to help it triple the turnover of the AMiT automation division within five years, which reached CZK 88m in 2022. The entire company reported an economic result exceeding CZK 500m.

Raiffeisenbank will stop making outgoing payments to Russia and Belarus as of February 15, 2023. Until now, the bank has been monitoring the payments and assessing their compliance with the applicable sanction regulations. Due to the development of the situation in Ukraine and after further tightening measures, the company has decided to stop their implementation.

Wolt has established cooperation with Shoptet. The Wolt Drive add-on will enable online retailers to deliver goods to customers in tens of minutes. In the first week, dozens of businesses have downloaded the app, for which express shipping is a step towards improving the customer experience. The plan is to expand the service to the Hungarian and Slovakian markets, where both entities operate.

E-shops with clothes and sneakers Footshop and Queens closed the year 2022 with a turnover of more than CZK 1bn. Footshop received 455,000 orders and sold 261,000 pairs of sneakers. The e-shop was visited by 30 million users and exceeded 1.5 million fans on social networks. Stone stores in Prague, Bucharest and Budapest were visited by 615 thousand customers. In 2023, Footshop plans to increase its e-commerce turnover by at least 10%, Queens by 35%. Queens is looking for a brick-and-mortar location in Prague, while Footshop is interested in opening a brick-and-mortar store in Poland and Slovakia.

The Regional Court in Ostrava ruled on the bankruptcy of the engineering company GEARWORKS from the WITKOWITZ group on January 24, 2023. The petition was filed by the company itself. It stated that it was negatively affected by the shortage of materials and their price increase as a result of the pandemic situation and the suspension of projects to the Russian Federation and Ukraine. GEARWORKS has 201 creditors, among the largest of which is Shape Steel with a claim of CZK 1.39m and Cilso International with CZK 1.02m.

The National Motorway Company (NDS) has confirmed CzechToll's victory in the tender for the supply of an electronic toll collection system including technical support. In its bid, CzechToll committed to develop and deliver the IS for EUR 13.8mexcluding VAT within 13 months of signing the contract. CzechToll CEO Petr Chvátal added that the system will enable the Slovak Ministry of Transport and NDS to implement strategic changes in the area of freight transport charging.

Financial group Moneta has increased the share of electric vehicles in its corporate fleet to 46% by the end of 2022. It currently owns 130 pure electric cars. By the end of 2023, it will have acquired nearly 60 new electric vehicles. Zuzana Filipová, the group's sustainability and communications director, added that the bank wants to achieve carbon neutrality by 2025 not only by exclusively purchasing electric vehicles, but also by reducing its fleet from the current 216 to 200 vehicles.

TTC Controls, owner of the UniControls brand, has entered into an exclusive distribution agreement with A-Paul Software Systems of India. The company will exclusively supply UniControls' technology transfer products to the Indian market, particularly in the area of overhead control and rolling stock information systems (TCMS).

The US OFAC has extended Sberbank CZ's exemption from sanctions imposed on selected Russian banks until January 31, 2024. The authority granted the insolvency administrator's request based on the steps it took to sell Sberbank's loan portfolio. The extension of the waiver is one of the main conditions for the settlement of the purchase agreement with Česka spořitelna (CS), which was signed in December 2022. Once CS pays the agreed purchase price, the migration of Sberbank's clients will begin. In the coming weeks, Sberbank plans to offer for sale the corporate bonds and the rest of the loan portfolio that are not part of the purchase agreement.

Prima group will launch its own video service on February 8, 2023. Prima+ will offer thousands of film and series titles alongside TV previews, including exclusive series under the Prima+ ORIGINALS banner. The streaming service will be available in three subscription tariffs ranging from a premium version without ads to ad-free viewing.

Jiří Rusnok will be an advisor to the board of directors of Allianz insurance company from February 1, 2023. Stefan de Goeij is the ESG and Energy Lead of the CTP Group. Zbyněk Slivoň is the CEO of AGC Automotive Czech. According to the Commercial Register, Tomáš Vlček has become Managing Director of ELDIS Pardubice.

Czech investment company McWin, which specialises in the food services sector, has bought a majority stake in German chain L'Osteria. The transaction values the acquired company at around EUR 400m. The acquisition is subject to regulatory requirements and is expected to close in 1Q 2023. L'Osteria operates 157 Italian restaurants in eight European markets.

In the year and a half since its launch, ČEZ Group's Lighting for CZK 1 project has saved municipalities an average of 78% of electricity. The power engineers have replaced a total of 6034 luminaires in 38 municipalities, whose total consumption has been reduced from 2189 MWh to 481 MWh. Municipalities do not buy the luminaires, but rent them. ČEZ Energetické služby pays for the renewal costs from the savings generated by replacing the old system with a new one.

The Liberec and Jablonec nad Nisou Municipal Transport Company (DPMLJ) has received eight SOR NS 12 buses for the end of 2022. This is the last part of the delivery from SOR Libchavy out of a total of twenty buses purchased at a cost of CZK 103m. They will gradually replace the outdated buses. The framework contract for the purchase of new diesel low-floor double-axle, three-door buses was signed in February 2020. The buses are diesel-powered and include passenger count monitoring equipment.

The Statutory City of Hradec Králové informed about the issuance of a building permit for the project: new construction of residential buildings (BD). The buildings will have one underground and seven above-ground floors. BD entrance A will have a built-up area of 1116.7 m2 and will house a total of 52 residential units. BD entrance B and C with a built-up area of 1574.6 m2 will have 97 residential units. The applicant is TOMAS INVEST. The town of Břeclav publishes information about the commencement of the construction procedure for the project: roads and pavements. The Statutory City of Karviná publishes information on the lease of business premises. The Statutory City of Pardubice informs about the lease of a restaurant.

The Moravian-Silesian Region (MSK) has announced a tender for the reconstruction and modernisation of the II/442 road in the section VD Kružberk - Svatoňovice - Čermná in Silesia for CZK 68.77m. The town of Jaroměř is requesting the lease of speed measuring equipment for CZK 43m. Mendel University in Brno (MENDELU) is looking for a supplier of information technology in a tender work CZK 40m. The City of Písek has launched a tender for CZK 42.47m for the reconstruction of building no. 85 on Alšovo náměstí square.

Dear readers, as we have already announced, we are currently gradually optimizing the offer of sector digests in the application. In this context, from 27 January 2023, FINANCE - Daily News digest you subscribed to will be automatically replaced by its new version with a more detailed structure, more comprehensive content and more precise targeting of individual sections.(ČIA)

Bezrealitky, a member of the European Housing Services (EHS) real estate group, and interior design startup Room Story are offering a new service called Quick Renovation to owners of older apartments in need of renovation. Under the scheme, the companies guarantee that the apartment will be renovated and fully furnished within three months at a pre-determined price. The service targets small investors. According to EHS Group head Hendrik Meyer, the platform aims to contribute to the transformation of the Czech housing market, which will increasingly lean towards rentals in the coming years. The number of people living in rentals in Prague could rise from around 35% at present to more than 45% in the next few years.(ČIA)

DAKO-CZ plans to establish a subsidiary in India, DAKO-CZ India, in 2023. It has set up two joint ventures in the country in 2022. Orders for the Indian market account for about a third of turnover. It expects further growth in Europe, Africa, and South America, where a completely new braking system will be implemented on the Automated People Mover project. This special train will operate at Brazil's Sao Paulo International Airport. For the coming years, DAKO-CZ also plans to expand into the North American market. The manufacturer of braking systems and components for rolling stock surpassed the two-billion-CZK sales mark for the first time in 2022, specifically rising year-on-year to CZK 2.09bn from CZK 1.55bn. Three-quarters of its production is exported.(ČIA)

The Ministry of Defence of the Czech Republic (MO) has received its first payment of EUR 6.5m from the EU as compensation for military material delivered to Ukraine. The compensation is being made through the European Peace Facility (EPF), which is used to finance EU priorities in the field of defence and security. So far, the Czech Republic has been recognised for reimbursement for supplies worth around EUR 80m, which will be paid out over the period 2023-2027. A total of EUR 3.1bn has been approved for compensation to EU member states so far. The EPF also finances, among other things, the EU's deployment mission to Ukraine (EUMAM), in which the Czech Republic is involved from December 2022.(ČIA)

Mortgage repayments on new flats in Prague could fall below the level of rent payments at the end of 2024. While the interest rate on mortgages was around 6% in December 2022, under the optimistic scenario it could fall to 4.5% at the end of 2023 and 3% per annum in December 2024. Rents in the metropolitan area rose by more than 20% y/y. The rate of growth is expected to slow slightly to 15% per annum this year and next. For a 70 m2 apartment, the monthly rent is expected to be CZK 37,600 in December 2024. The repayment for a 30-year mortgage at 3% interest would be CZK 35,800.(ČIA)

AMiT, a manufacturer of control systems for industrial automation and electronics for rolling stock and public transport, plans to spend tens of millions of crowns on foreign projects and the development of new technologies in the coming years. This is expected to help it triple the turnover of the AMiT automation division within five years, which reached CZK 88m in 2022. The entire company reported an economic result exceeding CZK 500m. AMiT was acquired by the industrial investment company Central Europe Industry Partners in August 2022. Aleš Krutina became the CEO.(ČIA)

Raiffeisenbank will stop making outgoing payments to Russia and Belarus as of February 15, 2023. Until now, the bank has been monitoring the payments and assessing their compliance with the applicable sanction regulations. Due to the development of the situation in Ukraine and after further tightening measures, the company has decided to stop their implementation. Incoming payments will be accepted if they do not contravene the applicable sanctions regulations and the Bank's sanctions policy.(ČIA)

The Agency for Enterprise and Innovation (API) has arranged over CZK 12bn in subsidy titles of the Operational Programme Enterprise and Innovation for Competitiveness (OP PIK) in 2022. In total, it processed more than 3,000 payment requests. The largest volume of support was drawn by entrepreneurs in the Applications, Energy Savings and Innovations programmes. Last year, the first calls were also announced in the follow-up Operational Programme Technology and Applications for Competitiveness. API received 360 applications for almost CZK 4.5bn. The biggest interest was in the Energy Savings, Innovation and Renewable Electricity - Wind Power call.(ČIA)

By the end of 2023, it will have acquired nearly 60 new electric vehicles. Zuzana Filipová, the group's sustainability and communications director, added that the bank wants to achieve carbon neutrality by 2025 not only by exclusively purchasing electric vehicles, but also by reducing its fleet from the current 216 to 200 vehicles. The bank will save not only on the operation of electric cars, but also on unpaid parking in Prague's blue zones.(ČIA)

The first unit from this order is already in production, which now totals 16 vehicles. Production is taking place at the production plant in Ostrava. The contract with Elron totals more than CZK 3.5bn. The delivery of the first six trains is scheduled for completion by the end of 2024. The units are built on the RegioPanter platform (trains in the Czech Republic and Slovakia), which was also used in the design of trains to neighbouring Latvia.(ČIA)

Czech investment company McWin, which specialises in the food services sector, has bought a majority stake in German chain L'Osteria. The transaction values the acquired company at around EUR 400m. The acquisition is subject to regulatory requirements and is expected to close in 1Q 2023. L'Osteria operates 157 Italian restaurants in eight European markets. The investment increases the number of restaurants in the portfolio of McWin and its affiliates to more than 1,500 across Europe.(ČIA)

Agency Moody's assigned J&T Bank an investment rating of Baa2 with a stable outlook and a short-term deposit rating of Prime-2. With this step, the bank joined several companies that have this rating in the Czech Republic and Slovakia. J&T CEO Štěpán Asher said that the bank's investment-grade rating opens up opportunities to raise capital on European and global markets.(ČIA)

The Railway Administration (SŽ) will spend an additional CZK 2.5bn on the reconstruction of dozens of station buildings in 2023. The company should, for example, start the renovation of buildings in the Ostrava-Vítkovice, Jaroměř, Letohrad, Hodonín, Hlinsko in Bohemia, Střelice, Senice na Hané or Jindřichov in Silesia stations. In 2022, SŽ invested approximately CZK 2.3bn in the repair of 36 buildings. Among the completed projects were the renovation of the facade of the Fanta building in Prague or the reconstruction in Havířov. From 2016 to 2021, SŽ repaired 284 buildings.(ČIA)

In 2022 there was an increase of 2,159 entities (13 % year-on-year) that do not pay VAT reliably or are marked as unreliable persons in the Czech Republic. Dun & Bradstreet (D&B) currently blacklists 26,158 entities. Of these, 4,934 are unreliable VAT payers and 21,224 are unreliable persons. D&B analyst Petra Štěpánová added that the number of unreliable VAT payers has slightly increased, which had started to decrease in 2018. On the contrary, the number of unreliable persons has been increasing continuously since 2017. The most unreliable companies are engaged in real estate rental and management, wholesale mediation and services.(ČIA)

Carriers paid CZK 14.85bn for the use of toll roads in the Czech Republic in 2022, a year-on-year increase of 4.6 %. Of this, CZK 13.22bn went to highways. CzechToll informed about this, stating that the total costs for the operation and development of the electronic toll system remained below CZK 1bn. In relation to revenues, as in the previous year, they did not exceed 7 %. Foreign carriers paid 51.5 % of the total collected tolls. In December alone, carriers paid CZK 1.05bn (-3 %). By the end of 2022, more than 743,000 vehicles with a weight over 3.5 tons (+100,000) were registered in the system. The number of on-board units issued to carriers exceeded 596,000.(ČIA)

The aggregate indicator of confidence in the economy expressed by the basic index increased by 2.3 points month-on-month to 92.0 in January 2023. The Czech Statistical Office reported that the confidence indicator of entrepreneurs increased by 1.3 points to 93.8 and that of consumers by 7.4 to 82.9. Business sentiment lifted after a five-month straight decline in industry. It also grew in trade and slightly in selected service sectors. In construction, it decreased for the second time in a row. The number of households assessing their current financial situation as worse than in the previous 12 months has fallen. The number of respondents expecting further deterioration of the situation in the next 12 months also decreased. Households are also less concerned about the deterioration of the overall economic situation. Around 28 % barely make ends meet with their finances and 10 % resort to savings or borrowing.(ČIA)

HR agency Předvýběr.CZ earned a total of CZK 76m in 2022. The company increased the number of employees to 60 last year and opened a branch in Brno. In addition to standard business activities supporting client relationships, the agency expanded its marketing care for job seekers and started to establish cooperation with universities. Předvýběr.CZ’s director František Boudný said that the company cooperates with the University of Economics in Prague and has started cooperation with the Czech Technical University.(ČIA)

President Miloš Zeman won the trust of 38% of Czechs at the turn of 2022 and 2023. Trust in the government has risen from 28% to 34%, according to a survey conducted by the Centre for Public Opinion Research (CVVM) of the Institute of Sociology of the Academy of Sciences, adding that of the constitutional institutions, respondents trusted mayors (71%) and municipal councils (69%) the most. The credibility of the Senate increased by 7 pp to 41%, while trust in the Chamber of Deputies increased by 5 pp to 33%. 16% of citizens were satisfied with the current political situation. 59% expressed dissatisfaction.(ČIA)

Filuta AI has received an investment of almost CZK 56m in a pre-seed round. The startup was supported by Nation 1, CzechFounders, SPM invest, as well as Microsoft's program for promising startups and the EU Horizon project for research and innovation. Filuta AI represents a new generation of composite AI that accelerates the actual development of automation by an order of magnitude, can optimize even complex processes and is accessible to small and medium-sized companies. It will use the funding to grow the team and accelerate technology development. CEO and co-founder Filip Dvořák said that development required 10 years of work and it would take the two founders five years to deliver the product to market. With 12 people, he can deliver it significantly sooner. This is a record amount raised by a Czech startup in a pre-seed round. The founders are already planning another investment round in 2024. Filuta is already piloting its business for Bohemia Interactive or Liftago, for example.(ČIA)

Coinwage and Fintree have entered into a strategic partnership that will bring synergies across both companies. Among other things, it will expand the market reach and a joint entry into Slovakia or Poland is being considered. Fintree co-founder Radim Oulehla added that the company is also buying a minority stake in Coinwage.(ČIA)

Trinity Bank has increased its share capital to CZK 2.76bn. The change was registered in the Commercial Register on January 20, 2023. The original amount was CZK 2.31bn.(ČIA)

SupplyDo reached a turnover of CZK 11m in 2022 and wants to increase it to CZK 250m in four years. Investors should help, with whom the Zlín-based startup is currently negotiating investments of up to tens of millions of CZK. The goal is also to expand the B2C segment and customer ranks to include Czech and European e-shops. SupplyDo was created a year ago in response to the needs of the changing supply environment and the growing demands of e-commerce. Founder David Klimek said SupplyDo offers services ranging from packaging and print design to product packaging and distribution for B2B and B2C customer networks.(ČIA)

Restaurants, pubs, and bars saw a 40% y/y increase in sales in 2022, according to data from the operator of the Dotykačka POS system for catering establishments, published by the Confederation of Commerce and Tourism of the Czech Republic. Owners in Prague are doing best, where the price increases that occurred last year have so far had the least effect. The Prague market is thus separating itself from the rest of the Czech Republic, according to Dotykačka director Petr Menclík. Village pubs are the worst off.(ČIA)

In 2022, Czech insurer Česká podnikatská pojišťovna (ČPP) solved a record number of insurance frauds worth almost CZK 90m. There were about 1,100 cases, which is almost double the year-on-year increase. The most numerous were frauds connected with car insurance. The ČPP stated that the number of insurance fraud attempts is gradually increasing. The reason is primarily the larger number of clients of the insurance company. The ČPP dealt with the most suspicions of fraud in Prague (17%) and in the Ústí Region (13%).(ČIA)

The high cost of security solutions and services is considered by 53% of executives to be the biggest barrier to ensuring a company's cybersecurity. The proble is reported by smaller enterprises (59%) more often than big businesses. The Sophos survey also shows that this problem is closely related to the lack of qualified staff, which is declared by 28% of executives. Lack of employee awareness was cited by 25% of managers. Problems related to the increased demands of remote working were cited by 27% of respondents. Employees' reluctance to implement protective measures is an obstacle to cybersecurity in 16% of Czech companies.(ČIA)

Insurer Allianz pojišťovna increases the amount of funds it protects each year against unauthorised payments to fraudsters. In 2022, this included 2,470 cases worth €368 million. CZK. Most cases were detected in Prague, where Allianz detectives focused on 423 cases with a total value of CZK 70.2m. Thanks to it, they don't have to wait for a mobile technician to arrive, but the software guides them on what to fill in and photograph. If the paperwork is in order, a quarter of claims are paid within two days and 60% within five days.(ČIA)

In total, 828 contracts had been concluded with a volume of CZK 1.13bn. The last date to apply for support for the reconstruction of a dwelling affected by the natural disaster of June 24, 2021 is June 23, 2023. A grant of up to CZK 2m and a loan of up to CZK 3m can be used for the reconstruction of dwellings. In the case of the loan, the interest rate is fixed for the entire repayment period and is 1 % pa, with a maximum repayment period of up to 25 years. The support is drawn down gradually.(ČIA)

Horse probably owned by Kadyrov stolen from stable in Czechia
582 字
2023 年 3 月 7 日 17:21 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Adds info, statements in last six paras.

Roudnice nad Labem, North Bohemia, March 7 (CTK) - An English thoroughbred worth almost 400,000 crowns, which is owned by Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov according to the server Jezdci.cz[https://www.jezdci.cz/clanky/zazou-beze-stopy-zmizel-nocni-unos-kadyrovova-hrebce-setri-policie/], has been stolen from a stable in Krabcice, North Bohemia, police spokeswoman Pavla Kofrova has said.

Kadyrov's stable has been registered with the Czech Jockey Club organisation since 2012. After Russia invaded Crimea in 2014 and the EU sanction became effective, the Czech Finance Ministry reduced the finance flow of the stable.

Last year, the daily Mlada fronta Dnes (MfD) wrote that Kadyrov owned exactly the Krabcice Darhorse stable.

The Chechen leader is one of the most powerful men in Russia and he keeps close relations with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The police said an unknown offender had probably stolen the horse in the night from Friday to Saturday. The sixteen-year-old bay horse has a white star-shaped mark on its forehead and part of his right back leg is also white.

The police are currently searching for the stolen horse and they ask the public for cooperation. In case anyone can provide any information, they are supposed to call the 158 police line or come directly to the nearest police station, Kofrova said.

The server Jezdci.cz said Kadyrov had bought the horse named Zazou in 2012. The horse has completed in the total of 36 races, having won nine times, winning over 1.2 million euros in total. Kadyrov has not been able to manipulate with the horse due to the anti-Russian sanctions.

Last January, that is before the Russian invasion of Ukraine, a couple of Russian-speaking men tried to transfer the horse from the stable, Czech Radio's Radiozurnal station reported, adding that Rostislav Kopecky, the owner of the stable, refused to give it up.

"They argued that they would take it to Poland and that they were allowed to transfer the frozen property within the EU," Kopecky told Radiozurnal.

He said the state had originally blocked five horses of Kadyrov. One of them, a stud horse, died last year. It was that horse, along with Zazou, that were probably the most valuable of all. The remaining three horses have been distributed each to a different stable in Czechia to stay there until the end of their life.

The Krabcice stable also previously hosted another stud horse, the ownership of which, however, Kadyrov transferred onto another person still before the sanctions were imposed on him. This horse has been exported from Czechia, according to Radiozurnal.

Confirming the information that the owner of Zazou is Kadyrov, Finance Ministry spokeswoman Michela Lagronova told Radiozurnal that if the owner of an animal, which is a racehorse in this case, appears on the list of those sanctioned, the state confiscates the animal but secures its prosperity. This applies to all animals. That is why the given horses have been entrusted to various stables to take care for them, Lagronova said.

The horses could continue racing, but the possible gains could not go to a person figuring on the list of sanctions.

"If the sanctions last long and the animal dies in the meantime, no duty of the state arises from this towards the person under sanctions," Lagronova said.

She would not comment on alleged attempts to export Kadyrov's horse from Czechia.

($1 = 22.112 crowns)

Ideas
Czechs stand with Ukraine
Borek Lizec
National Post
1150 字
2023 年 3 月 8 日
National Post
FINP
National
A15
英文
© 2023 National Post . All Rights Reserved.
For a Czech, it is particularly emotional to watch the war in Ukraine. Our historical experience of the 20th century urges us to think how much we have learnt from the past. Under the Munich Agreement of September 1938, Hitler and Mussolini, as well as our allies Chamberlain and Daladier, demanded that Czechoslovakia cede its border regions to Nazi Germany. This was supposed to be Hitler's last territorial demand in Europe. Peace in Europe was to be saved. Half a year later, in March 1939, Germany invaded the rest of the Czech lands, defenceless after giving up its fortifications along with the surrendered territory. The world just watched. Hitler gained the strong Czechoslovak war production capacity (Czechoslovakia with its major industrial base ranked among the world's 10 most developed countries) and grew in strength.

As the West, we neglected to respond to the "Munich moment" when Russia annexed Crimea. However, we did act on the "March 1939 moment" by intervening when the ruthless aggressor, with a total disregard for human life, grasped for the whole country. As we learned in 1938, appeasement does not lead to a lasting peace. It is such a relief for the Czech to see this historical lesson reflected in the actions of the united West.

Czechs also experienced a Russian invasion when they tried to break away from the Soviet empire of evil in 1968. We could not be helped. The risk of nuclear confrontation must have seemed too great for the West to intervene. We had to stay behind the Iron Curtain. The devastating Russian occupation lasted more than 20 years. The videos of Ukrainians waving their flags, shouting at the occupants to go home, are very familiar to me. I know them from films of 1968 Prague. With my experience of growing up behind the Iron Curtain, it is wonderful to see the shared determination of the West to help Ukraine liberate its whole territory and get those taken to Russia back home, starting with children. No Ukrainian must be left behind the new Russian Iron Curtain.

We will never forget that Canada stood by us when we faced the Nazi and Soviet occupations. During the Second World War, Canada, among other things, supported the Czechoslovak government in exile, trained our RAF pilots and even helped us succeed in one of the most important acts of Nazi resistance on occupied territories during the war - the assassination of a principle architect of the Holocaust, Reinhard Heydrich. During the Cold War, Canada admitted more than 36,000 Czechs and Slovak emigrants. Today, Canada stands firmly with us again. You were helping Europe face the Russian threat well before the invasion. You have led the NATO mission deterring Russia from attacking Latvia. The training you have provided to more than 35,000 Ukrainian soldiers has been an important factor in the war.

It has been an honour for the Czech Republic to be one of Ukraine's strongest partners in its fight for freedom and humanism. The Czech government has provided more than $600,000 in military aid, and the Czech defence industry has added $1.8 million. These supplies have included 89 tanks, 226 combat and armoured vehicles, 1.5 million pieces of ammunition, including 60,000 rockets, four combat helicopters, 38 howitzers, six anti-aircraft defence systems, and 900 metres of bridge structures. I shall add that our allies have been supporting us in these efforts by granting us compensation for the donated equipment. The U.S. has provided us with Viper and Venom helicopters, and Germany has supplied Leopard tanks. I am proud of Czech citizens and the support they have extended to the brave people of Ukraine. Czechs have accommodated in their homes a high share of the 460,000 refugees who have applied for temporary protection status in our country (Czechia has received the highest number of refugees per capita of all countries), raised more than $245 million, and even bought a tank nicknamed "Thomas the Tank."

The wave of support among Czech Canadians, from descendants of the first Czech cowboys in the Prairies to those who have arrived recently, has impressed me as well. Some of the efforts have been quite creative. The New Moon tattoo studio in Ottawa offered special motifs of a Molotov cocktail or a tank pulled by a tractor for a donation of $100 for Ukraine. This is how Milena Fusco wanted to commemorate the fate of her mother, who fled Czechoslovakia in 1968.

Many of those who have had a family experience with the Soviets seizing control of my country have been making sure throughout their lives that the communist crimes are not forgotten. Among them, long-term community leader Robert Tmej has supported the creation of the Victims of Communism monument in Ottawa. After the outbreak of war in Ukraine, Russia found a peculiar way to "reward" him for his efforts. Together with the highest representatives of Canada, Moscow put him onto its sanction list. This step illustrates how strongly Vladimir Putin's Russia positions itself in the role of the Soviet Union's direct successor. It does not distance itself even from the horrors committed by communist regimes.

Determined to recreate the Soviet Empire, Putin has demanded the clock be rolled back to 1997. The Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary joined NATO in 1999. At this point, we should believe that he will attempt to do what he says, no matter how crazy and overambitious such plans may sound. It was a mistake for the world not to believe Hitler's Mein Kampf in 1938. Putin seems to have followed his long-term plans. Last year's invasion seems to explain why Russian agents blew up the Vrbetice depots in the Czech Republic, a unique source of Soviet-type artillery ammunition that was destined for Ukraine, back in 2014.

Ukraine is fighting for democracy, humanism, rules-based order, and the survival of countries at least in its vicinity, including the Czech Republic. We shall never forget the sacrifices made by the Ukrainian people, unimaginable for our generations who grew up in peace. Our transatlantic friend, Canada, deserves our gratitude for its lasting support as well.

Special to National Post Borek Lizec is Ambassador of the Czech Republic to Canada

Ukraine needs more sanctions against Russia - Czech diplomat
469 字
2023 年 3 月 12 日 18:45 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, March 12 (CTK) - It is important for Ukraine to strengthen sanctions against propagandists of the Russian regime of Vladimir Putin, against celebrities that influence opinions in Russian society, Czech ambassador to Kyiv Radek Matula has told CTK.

"These people speak against Ukraine, against Ukrainian partners. At the same time, they travel to the countries of the European Union, to the United States without any limits. If they are artists, they have concerts there, spend their holidays there, their children study there," he said.

Matula said Ukraine will certainly keep calling for stricter sanctions imposed on Russian financial institutions, against banks. He also expects Ukrainian demands for trade restrictions and sanctions that would prevent production of the Russian military industry complex.

At the end of February, the EU agreed on the tenth package of sanctions that includes more restrictions of exports of dual use products and measures against entities supporting war, spreading propaganda or delivering drones that Russia uses in attacks.

Matula said the Ukrainian representatives are aware of that three sanction packages were approved during the six-month Czech presidency of the Council of the EU.

In late March, a so-called sanction forum will take place in Kyiv in which sanction coordinators from Western countries will participate.

Matula said the sanctions are not devastating for the Russian economy, but they often affect it only after some time.

He said that the West knows that Ukraine must not lose the war. "If Ukraine loses, it will be a signal for Russia that it may go further in its imperial ambitions," he pointed out. If Ukraine falls, it is only a question of time when Russia will want to move further on," Matula said.

As for military support, deliveries of anti-aircraft defence systems and artillery ammunition are the priorities for Ukraine now, he said.

Matula said Ukraine is letting us know that it is ready to defend the NATO territory and Western values. "We support Ukraine's membership in NATO as soon as it is possible. It is not possible at present when there is the war," he noted.

Czechia also clearly supports the EU accession process for Ukraine. "The Ukrainian side has been doing its utmost to meet all the seven conditions set by the European Commission with the candidate status as soon as possible," Matula said. However, this is not easy in a standard situation, and Ukraine is in a nonstandard one, he noted.

The Ukrainian leaders have the advantage that the public supports the memberships of the EU and NATO, he said. "Ukrainians want to be part of our space. They don't want to be part of the post-Soviet space and they certainly don't want to be part of Russia," Matula said.

Dozens of Czech castles are controlled by Russian oligarchs
329 字

bne IntelliNews

© 2023. bne IntelliNews. All Rights reserved.
Ownership of dozens of historical castles and chateaus in Czechia is linked to sanctioned oligarchs from Russia, public broadcaster Czech Television (CT) reported[https://ct24.ceskatelevize.cz/domaci/3573447-rusti-podnikatele-v-cesku-vlastni-desitky-historickych-budov-investice-vysetruje]. Some of these include the picturesque Hruba Skala chateau located in the Cesky Raj nature park or the baroque chateau in the South Bohemian town of Protivin.

“The chateau is not owned by the town, it has a private owner,” Protivin town counsellor Milan Mraz told CT. The chateau was bought by Malaysian sultan Muhammad V. of Kelantan, and according to the business registry, it is controlled by a Manchester-based company represented by Russian businessman Khasan Kuchakov.

Chateau representative Vera Nagyova told CT that neither she nor Kuchakov was ever in the ownership structure.

The Financial and Analytical Office has been investigating ownership structures of some 30 chateaus, and CT reported that more Czech chateaus and castles are on sale at the Russian websites. Czech authorities are working on a national sanction list, with the first names expected to be known in two months.

Czechia has been for years a popular destination for Russian oligarchs and the affluent Russian elite. Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February, Czech media and authorities have been paying increased attention to Russian-owned properties and some of their local business partners.

Many of the owners, including AFK Sistema of Putin ally Vladimir Yevtushenkov, which owned electronics company STROM, or Evraz shareholders Alexander Abramov and Alexander Frolov, who owned the Oaks Prague real estate project, have sold or passed on the control of their assets in Czechia.

Earlier this week, Russian oligarch and former vice president of Transneft Mikhail Arustamov was reported to have shifted ownership of many of his real estate assets in Prague. Arustamov has been the beneficiary of a long-term cheap rent contract concluded in the 1990’s with Prague municipality for the lucrative business and cultural complex Slovansky dum [Slavonic house] in the city centre.

Prague, April 20 (CTK) - Security affairs are one of the key aspects of Czech-Latvian relations, Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) told journalists today, adding that he is going to talk about them with his Latvian counterpart Edgars Rinkevics in Riga on Friday.

Lipavsky said he plans to discuss the response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, cooperation in the European Union as well as China, the Indo-Pacific and sanctions with Rinkevics.

News
Czechs look to dump Russian nuclear fuel
Tim Gosling
1415 字
2023 年 5 月 4 日 13:05 GMT
Al Jazeera English
AJAZEN
英文
Copyright 2023 Al Jazeera English.
Pressure is rising to include the Russian nuclear sector in the European Commission’s 11th sanction package plans.

Click to view image[https://www.google-analytics.com/collect?v=1&tid=UA-1615344-99&dl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aljazeera.com%2Fnews%2F2023%2F5%2F4%2Fczechs-look-to-dump-russian-nuclear-fuel&cid=cGFydG5lci1kb3dqb25lcw%3D%3D&t=pageview&cd2=post-aje-2182981&cd3=cGFydG5lci1kb3dqb25lcw%3D%3D]

Prague, Czech Republic – One chilly night in early April, a pair of Spanish-owned planes left Helsinki Airport loaded with pipes bearing radiation hazard symbols.

Their destination was Brno, the Czech Republic’s second city.

These nocturnal manoeuvres have become regular over the past 14 months.

With Russian planes banned from European Union skies, Finland is now a regular stop for imports of nuclear fuel from the east, which currently runs approximately 20 percent of Europe’s nuclear fleet.

Dependence among former Eastern Bloc countries operating Soviet-built reactors is especially heavy, and has helped block efforts to levy sanctions against Rosatom, Russia’s state nuclear agency.

But the client list of TVEL, Rosatom’s fuel arm, is shrinking. From 2024, Finnish air cargo handlers should no longer be required to load planes bound for the Czech Republic, and other routes could also soon be abandoned.

In March, Czech state-controlled energy group CEZ announced that from next year Westinghouse will supply fuel for the Dukovany nuclear power plant’s (NPP) four Soviet-supplied VVER-440 units.

France’s Framatome joined the US company in signing a similar deal to fuel Temelin’s twin VVER-1000 reactors last year.

Click to view image[https://www.aljazeera.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/INTERACTIVE-Russian-gas-imports-in-2019.jpg?w=770&resize=770%2C770]

Race

“After the war in Ukraine broke out last year, CEZ immediately started talks to find a new fuel supplier for security reasons,” the Czech company said.

But as a staunch supporter of Ukraine, the Czech Republic – which holds reserves to last three years – also understands that reducing dependence on Russian fuel should help open the way to sanction Rosatom, which helps fill the Kremlin’s war chest and, as Ukraine’s ambassador to the EU Vsevolod Chertsov told a European Parliament meeting on April 25 “works hand in hand with the Russian military”.

Pressure to include the Russian nuclear sector has built as the European Commission plans an 11th package of sanctions. However, the discussion is far from straightforward.

Rosatom supplies fuel to more than a dozen European NPPs, according to Olena Pavlenko from Ukrainian energy think tank Dixi, and controls close to 50 percent of the global uranium enrichment market.

With this in mind, Rosatom’s Western competitors have been racing to develop fuels that can replace TVEL’s.

Russia insists that is a risk.

“Safety must remain the top priority,” TVEL told Al Jazeera. “Decisions must be based on transparency and technological efficiency, rather than political considerations.”

And even campaigners like Vladimir Slivyak at Russian NGO Ecodefense acknowledge “it’s a question whether Westinghouse can really supply this fuel by 2024”.

Many nuclear experts suggest that developing a new fuel usually takes at least two years. Westinghouse did not respond to questions regarding its progress.

National regulators also need to license new fuels.

“It typically takes around seven-eight years,” claims TVEL, “before a new supplier may begin full-scale commercial fuel supplies.”

However, given the political impetus, it seems likely that licensing decisions could be swift. The European Commission pledged last year to help fast-track the process.

War chest

Nuclear fuel sales contribute relatively little to the Kremlin’s coffers, but the nuclear sector as a whole drives significant income and access to key technology from overseas. Rosatoms’s earnings in 2021 ran to about $20bn.

“Rosatom controls a nuclear market valued at 180 billion euros,” says Lithuanian MEP Andrius Kubilius. “The obvious question is why the EU is not sanctioning this company.”

But the answer is just as clear: Russia’s control of the fuel and enrichment market.

Washington is in a similar bind. Rosatom holds a share of the US enrichment market. However, it is claimed that the White House is ready to move regardless.

“The Biden administration understands that certain EU member states oppose sanctioning Rosatom and is hesitant to proceed without a consensus,” suggest analysts at Washington, DC-based think tank Foundation for Defense of Democracies.

Bulgaria, Hungary and France are believed to be the main obstacles to waging EU sanctions.

The former pair rely on Russian fuel. France produces its own, but sources 15 percent of the enriched uranium it needs from Russia.

However, change is in the air.

The CEZ’s Ledvice coal-fired power plant [File: David W Cerny/Reuters][https://www.aljazeera.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/2016-03-15T120000Z_472254050_D1AESSQZOMAH_RTRMADP_3_CZECH-ENERGY-1683016470.jpg?w=770&resize=770%2C447]

Against the grain

On April 16, Paris signed an agreement alongside the United States, Canada, Japan, and the United Kingdom, to squeeze Russia out of the international nuclear fuel market.

Meanwhile, like the Czechs, Bulgaria and others operating Soviet-era NPPs – which are currently fully dependent on TVEL – are pushing to diversify.

Last year, Sofia signed deals with Westinghouse and Framatome for fuel supplies for the two reactors at the Kozloduy plant starting in 2024 and 2025. Slovakia has launched a tender for a new supplier and is talking with the same suppliers.

Finland is also planning to dump TVEL when its contracts expire in 2030, while a contract for Rosatom to build a new reactor has also been terminated.

The trend is keenly encouraged by Ukraine. Kyiv’s bid to break with TVEL began after Russia’s 2014 occupation of Crimea, and by 2019 one of its VVER-1000 units was loaded with US fuel.

“Ukraine is the first country that managed to diversify. We’ve shown it’s possible to find an alternative fuel and certify it,” says Chertsov. “But some EU countries still seem unwilling.”

That barb is aimed squarely at Hungary, which as so often is going against the grain. Viktor Orban’s government has refused to pivot away from Putin and Budapest has instead worked to complicate EU sanctions. It has threatened to veto any action against the Russian nuclear sector.

A 2014 contract that Orban struck directly with the Russian president to expand the Paks NPP, which provides about 40 percent of Hungary’s power, is key to that stance. Under the deal, Moscow is providing 10 billion euros ($11bn) in financing.

“Paks 2 is the elephant in the room when it comes to agreeing EU sanctions against Rosatom,” says Slivyak.

On the one hand, Orban appears determined to see the project through. On the other, it is badly behind schedule as Rosatom struggles to meet EU safety requirements. But Budapest this month dismissed the opportunity to back out to agree on amendments to the contract.

Budapest is already under immense pressure from Western partners, and its track record suggests it is unlikely to continue to block nuclear sanctions should it find itself standing alone.

Many suspect that, as with oil and gas sanctions, Hungary is hanging on in the hope of winning a carve to allow Rosatom to build Paks 2.

Two-way street

Hungary’s EU partners could hand over that plum and yet prevent Russia from building a new NPP inside the bloc.

“Sanctioning the nuclear sector would be great, but there’s another route also,” says Sebastian Rotters from German NGO Urgewald. “The dependency goes both ways. Rosatom relies on the likes of France and Germany to supply high-tech equipment. Halting such exports wouldn’t need agreement from 27 states.”

Leveraging that dependency could stop Paks 2. Hungary complains that Berlin is “blocking” Siemens from delivering control systems for the project.

But it could also be used to have a deeper and wider effect, should Western governments find the courage to take on such powerful companies.

While nuclear fuel is a relatively minor earner for Russia, Rosatom’s operation constructing new NPPs around the globe is far more lucrative, both financially and in terms of geopolitical influence.

The company hopes to build 30 NPPs across Asia, North Africa, and South America, among other spots, in the coming years, asserts Pavlenko from Dixi.

Akkuyu, Turkey’s first NPP, built and operated by Rosatom, was inaugurated in late April.

“Framatome and Siemens are supplying the ‘brains’ for Rosatom’s NPPs,” Pavlenko says.

“If these companies didn’t ship key technologies it would prevent Russia spreading its influence and the potential for further nuclear terrorism,” she says, pointing at Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia plant, Russia’s occupation of which has spurred deep safety concerns.

“It could also stop Rosatom’s habit of passing on certain equipment to the Russian military,” says Rotter.

CTK's Business News in Brief
1347 字
2023 年 5 月 17 日 18:41 GMT
CTK Business News
CTK
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Company transformation to require fewer votes - bill

------------------------------------------------------------

Prague - The government today approved a bill that reduces the required majority of shareholder votes for the transformation of companies from the current 90 percent to 75 percent of the votes of the shareholders present at a general meeting, Justice Minister Pavel Blazek told the press after the cabinet meeting.

At the same time, the required quorum will increase to more than two-thirds of the share capital. The Justice Ministry's original proposal envisaged 85 percent of the votes of those present upon a two-third attendance. In January, the government's Legislative Council did not recommend adopting this passage, which reacted to the state's position in the CEZ energy group. The state owns 70 percent of CEZ. Prime Minister Petr Fiala said earlier the government is counting on restructuring the company, with one of the options being its division. The aim should be for the state to gain control over the energy infrastructure.

Small farmers support cuts in non-investment subsidies

------------------------------------------------------------

Prague - The Association of Private Farming, which associates small farmers in Czechia, agrees to cuts in non-investment subsidies within the government's plan to reduce the state budget deficit, the association's board said in a press release today.

National subsidies in the Czech Republic are the fifth highest in the EU, and thanks to lobbying, the biggest companies have drawn them in recent years, the association said. A decade ago, the volume of national subsidies was around Kc1bn a year, and last year it rose to Kc5bn mainly in favour of large companies, according to the association. The subsidies need to have a limit, it added. In its plan to consolidate public finances, the government has said it wants to save more than Kc10bn in national agricultural subsidies over the next two years.

ERU plans to increase fees for gas transport through Czechia

-----------------------------------------------------

Prague - The Czech Energy Regulatory Office (ERU) is planning to sharply raise fees for gas transport across the Czech territory from January 1, 2024, Czech economic daily Ekonomicky denik[https://ekonomickydenik.cz/energeticky-regulator-pomuze-spolecnosti-net4gas-skokove-zvysi-poplatky-za-prepravu-plynu-pres-cesko/] reported today.

According to the daily, ERU will thus aid gas transporter Net4Gas, which is sustaining losses as less gas is flowing through the Czech Republic after the Nord Stream pipeline was shut down. The impact on prices for Czech customers should be negligible, according to ERU's estimates, the daily's website noted.

Shift from coal to cause long-term electricity deficit - association

------------------------------------------------------------

Prague - The planned shift away from coal will put Czechia into a large and long-term electricity deficit, which will lead to a significant increase in market prices, representatives of the Realistic Energy and Ecology group told journalists today.

The government's plan to phase out coal-fired power generation by 2033 is hasty because there is no relevant replacement for it now, according to the group that associates about 30 Czech scientists and experts. The situation will not be solved by the possible replacement of coal by a large number of new solar power plants, they said, pointing to problems in winter, during which the share of photovoltaics in the total production is minimal. The association also sees the possible replacement of coal with gas as a serious risk, as it would be necessary to secure large quantities of the commodity. The future lies in nuclear energy, the association said. According to nuclear scientist Vladimir Wagner, Czechia needs to gradually build two new reactors at Dukovany and then at Temelin, and eventually decide on other sites for large units and small modular reactors.

Aero Vodochody opening development centre in Brno

------------------------------------------------------------

Brno - Aircraft manufacturer Aero Vodochody is opening a development centre in Brno and plans to take on about 30 employees by the end of this year, vice president Petr Jinda said in a press release.

The development centre focuses on the development of avionics systems and interactive interface documentation for the L-39NG trainer aircraft. Aero is currently continuing production of the first L-39NG aircraft for Vietnam. The company is to complete 10 units this year, 16 units next year, and the production capacity on the recently launched production line may rise to two aircraft a month in the coming years. Aero now has orders for 34 units, with customers including Hungary. Other contracts are being negotiated, for example with Slovakia. Its production capacity is full until 2025.

Skoda JS removed from US sanctions list - company spokesman

----------------------------------

Plzen, West Bohemia - Czech nuclear energy equipment producer Skoda JS has been removed from the US sanctions list, as the company has been fully owned by Czech energy group CEZ since last November, when CEZ acquired it from Russia's engineering group OMZ controlled by Gazprombank, Skoda JS spokesman Jan Stolar told CTK today.

As of May 12, Skoda JS is no longer subject to restrictions based on US sanction legislation with respect to Russia, Stolar said. The Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) of the US Department of the Treasury has published an official notification of Skoda JS's removal from the Sectoral Sanctions Identifications List, available at https://ofac.treasury.gov/recent-actions/20230512,[https://ofac.treasury.gov/recent-actions/20230512,] he said. By buying Skoda JS from OMZ, CEZ significantly boosted Czechia's energy security, according to Stolar.

Amazon to rent hall in northern Bohemia to print T-shirts

--------------------------------------------------

Chomutov, North Bohemia - Internet retailer Amazon will rent a hall in a zone near Chomutov to print T-shirts, with 200 people to get jobs in the facility, as Amazon has taken over the building from developer Panattoni, Panattoni told CTK.

The area of the Amazon facilities is almost 15,000 square metres. The hall will be used to produce custom-printed T-shirts and accessories as part of the Amazon Merch[https://merch.amazon.com/landing] service. The hall will start operating by the end of this year, Amazon spokesman in Czechia Noah Zyla told CTK. It will serve both Czech and foreign customers, Zyla added. In Czechia, Amazon operates distribution centres in Dobroviz near Prague and in Kojetin, northern Moravia.

Interest in material handling equipment on rise in Czechia

--------------------------------------------------

Prague - There is a growing interest in material handling equipment (MHE) in the Czech Republic, with 12,090 units of all types and brands sold in 2022, 11 units more than in the record year of 2021, MHE company Jungheinrich said.

Demand increased mainly in electrically driven equipment, while internal combustion engine technology saw a decline, according to Jungheinrich. Sales of MHE in the Czech Republic increased despite a 12 percent annual drop in demand across Europe.

Skoda's new car sales in EU up 42.1 pct yr/yr in April - ACEA

-------------------------------------------------------

Brussels - Czech carmaker Skoda Auto, a unit of German group Volkswagen, saw its new passenger car sales in the European Union rise by 42.1 percent yr/yr to 45,922 units in April, the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA) said in a press release[https://www.acea.auto/pc-registrations/new-car-registrations-17-2-in-april-battery-electric-11-8-market-share/] today.

Skoda's share in the EU market thus rose to 5.7 percent from 4.7 percent a year ago, ACEA said.

Slovakia to take measures to consolidate public finance

------------------------------------------------------------

Bratislava (CTK correspondent) - Slovakia will have to take measures to consolidate public finances as it cannot afford to continue running a high deficit, and decisions will have to be made on both the revenue and expenditure sides, Prime Minister Ludovit Odor and Finance Minister Michal Horvath told journalists today.

Odor's caretaker cabinet will prepare proposals for the next government that will emerge from the early election in September. For this year, the Slovak state budget expects the share of the public sector deficit in GDP to reach up to 6.44 percent. "This figure is high in European comparison. It is not a problem to have a 6 percent% deficit in one year, but it is a problem if we do nothing and the 6 percent deficit continues," Odor said. "Unless the state takes further measures, the public finance deficits in the coming years will be unsustainable for Slovakia. We will have to consolidate public finances," Horvath said.

Washington, May 19 (CTK) - The Versvet company, seated in the Czech Republic, is the target of a new package of anti-Russian sanctions of the United States, as it helped a Russian firm circumvent trade restrictions, the U.S. Treasury Department has announced[https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy1494].

According to Washington, the company was involved in the Russian firm Radioavtomatika's efforts to import electronics despite being placed on the sanctions since the start of Russia's aggression against Ukraine.

Radioavtomatika specialises in providing foreign equipment for Russia's defense industry and has repeatedly sought to import it through various intermediaries since it was sanctioned last year. One of them was Versvet, which is owned and controlled by Russian citizen Svetlana Verkhovtseva, according to the U.S. statement.

The U.S. Department of the Treasury sanction body, the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), today imposed sanctions on both Verkhovtseva and her company.

Firm seated in Czechia target of new US anti-Russian sanctions
402 字
2023 年 5 月 19 日 17:48 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Adds Czech ministry's reaction in paras 2, 7.

Washington, May 19 (CTK) - The Versvet company, seated in the Czech Republic, is the target of a new package of anti-Russian sanctions of the United States, as it helped a Russian firm circumvent trade restrictions, the U.S. Treasury Department has announced[https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy1494].

Addressed by CTK, the Czech Finance Ministry said that it can only enforce sanctions figuring on the lists of the EU and the UN, and those on Czechia's own national list of sanctions.

According to Washington, the company was involved in the Russian firm Radioavtomatika's efforts to import electronics despite being placed on the sanction list since the start of Russia's aggression against Ukraine.

Radioavtomatika specialises in providing foreign equipment for Russia's defence industry and has repeatedly sought to import it through various intermediaries since it was sanctioned last year. One of them was Versvet, which is owned and controlled by Russian citizen Svetlana Verkhovtseva, according to the U.S. statement.

The U.S. Department of the Treasury sanction body, the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), today imposed sanctions on both Verkhovtseva and her company.

Versvet is based in Karlovy Vary, west Bohemia, on Belgrade Street that, is in the town's commercial and administrative centre. Apart from the spa zone, this part of town is one of the most attractive.

The Czech Finance Ministry told CTK that all information about the U.S. actions has been monitored by the Financial Analytical Office (FAU), which is in charge of sanctions-related measures in the Czech Republic. However, based on the current regulations, it can only carry out these measures on persons or entities on the EU or UN sanctions lists, or on the Czech list based on the so-called Magnitsky Law, ministry spokeswoman Michaela Lagronova said.

Today, the OFAC is targeting additional individuals and entities affiliated with Radioautomatic, the U.S. Treasury Department has written.

In total, it today cracked down on 22 people and 104 entities with points of contact in more than 20 countries or jurisdictions. These sanctions mean that all assets of the named entities are blocked in the U.S., and that U.S. citizens and persons on U.S. soil are prohibited from conducting transactions with the entities unless authorized by the OFAC.

Businessman Yevtushenkov, his son put on Czech sanction list
244 字
2023 年 6 月 28 日 21:54 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, June 28 (CTK) - The Czech Republic has put Russian businessman Vladimir Yevtushenkov and his son Felix on its internal sanction list, the government decided at its meeting today, according to the list on the website[https://www.mzv.cz/jnp/cz/zahranicni_vztahy/sankcni_politika/sankcni_seznam_cr/vnitrostatni_sankcni_seznam.html] of the Foreign Ministry.

Two months ago, Patriarch Kirill of Moscow was the first person placed on the list due to his support for the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Persons on the list are banned from entering Czechia, any assets they would have in the country are frozen, and no financial operations through Czech entities is allowed.

Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) said tonight that the Yevtushenkov family could have and still may have some property in Czechia. The Financial Analytical Office will check this and freeze the possible property.

Lipavsky said that the business of Yevtushenkov in Russia concerns military industry. Companies connected with the JSFC Sistema concern founded and co-owned by Yevtushenkov make and deliver arms systems for Russian arms forces.

Czech Radio reported last year that Yevtushenkov owns the Savoy Westend Hotel in the Czech spa town Karlovy Vary.

Lipavsky said Vladimir Yevtushenkov and his son provides considerable sources to the Russian government. "In the past, he repeatedly stayed on Czech territory, which he cannot do any more," Lipavsky said.

The inclusion on the national sanctions list is made possible by the government's "Magnitsky law," which came into force in January.

Czechia terminates oil transportation contract with PKN OrlenState-owned company Mero, which operates the oil pipeline infrastructure and oil reserves in Czechia, terminated the contract with Polish oil importer PKN Orlen’s Czech branch ...

Czechia urges outreach to third countries before further Russia sanctions
Aurélie Pugnet
565 字
2023 年 7 月 20 日 10:30 GMT
EurActiv.com
EURACOM
英文
Copyright 2023. EurActiv.com All Rights Reserved.
Even if the EU continues economic sanctions on Russia, focus should be put on rallying the rest of the world’s support for Ukraine, Czechia’s Deputy Foreign Minister Jan Marian told EURACTIV in an interview.

EU member states approved in June the latest eleventh Russia sanctions package[https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/eu-greenlights-11th-russia-sanctions-package-mostly-targeted-at-stuffing-loopholes/] since Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, designed to prevent third countries and companies from circumventing the bloc’s existing measures.

“There is definitely room for another [package] plus looking into loopholes and evasion of sanctions,” Marian said.

With negotiations becoming more and more difficult when it comes to agreeing on economic sanctions, Europeans have been looking at filling in the gaps in the sanctions and promoting their measures to third countries in the hope they will follow them.

“The buzzword now is outreach and (…) talking to third countries, in bordering regions being Central Asia or the Caucasus, talking to the partners in the South, with Africa or South America,” he added.

He stayed firm on continuing sanctions against Moscow, in whatever form they might take.

“As people say, the biggest room in the world is the room for improvement, and I think there are many areas we can still touch upon,” Marian said about implementing EU sanctions without going into specifics.

“Of course, there might be some logical national sensitive issues, some dependencies,” to take into account, he added.

The Czech Republic still benefits from imports of Russian oil,[https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/hungary-wants-russia-sanctions-exemption-extended-ensure-oil-exports-to-czechia/] on which it depends for its energy security.

For the same reason, it has been reluctant, alongside other member states – to sanction nuclear energy imports provided by Russia to the bloc, although Baltic countries and Poland, especially, have been calling for the EU to sanction state company Rosatom[https://www.euractiv.com/section/europe-s-east/news/pressure-mounts-on-eu-to-sanction-rosatom-in-next-russia-sanctions-package/].

Outreach key

Marian said that EU member states would need to reach out to third countries more to rally them to the Ukraine cause.

Outreach “is something we do both on the EU [and the national level], and we coordinate with other like-minded colleagues”, he added.

While EU sanctions had been planned in coordination with G7 partners and have been followed by other European countries, for instance, in the Western Balkans, the bloc has faced backlash from third countries[https://www.euractiv.com/section/global-europe/news/how-europe-seeks-to-battle-russias-charm-offensive-in-africa/], which have been hesitant to condemn Russia’s aggression against Ukraine.

Russia’s President Vladimir Putin has accused the West of being responsible for risking food security[https://www.euractiv.com/section/europe-s-east/news/eu-breaks-fertiliser-deadlock-approves-ninth-russia-sanctions-package/] around the world by imposing sanctions on Russia.

“We talked to the Ukrainians who are more active in Africa now. We help them. And I think this is very important,” Marian said about Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky’s recent diplomatic outreach to African countries.

National initiative

With its national equivalent of the American ‘Magnitsky Act’, a human rights violation sanctions regime, the Czech Republic has been able to sanction individuals the EU member states have not.

Three Russians have been blacklisted by the Czech Republic, including Patriarch Kirill, the listing of whom was refused by Hungary multiple times, who “was joined by another two businessmen from Russia who have properties in Czechia”, Marian said.

“There are more to come,” he said, adding that the national sanctions regime would be “a complementary tool”.

“In case there is not an agreement on the EU level, we can still do something on the national level, Marian said.

[Edited by Alexandra Brzozowski/Alice Taylor]

Czechia may add Russian arms dealer's son-in-law to sanction list

Prague, July 20 (CTK) - Czech Interior Minister Vit Rakusan (Mayors and Independents, STAN) and Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky (Pirates) will examine the possibility of adding Rostislav Zorikov, the son-in-law of Russian arms dealer Boris Obnosov, to the national sanction list, Rakusan said on Twitter[https://twitter.com/Vit_Rakusan/status/1681960462424985600?s=20] today.

Czech diplomacy head Lipavsky told CTK that he would not comment on the process of adding people to the list because it is in a classified mode.

The Aktualne.cz[https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/rus-bohatne-na-valce-zije-v-praze/r~73afed5623f811eeb1f50cc47ab5f122/] server reported today that Zorikov lives in Prague and is using money from Russia's aggression in Ukraine to buy real estate and cars. The web writes that a week ago, he also got into a scuffle with an activist in Prague's Zizkov district who wanted to protest against the family's involvement in war production.

The server says that Obnosov's company, KTRV, manufactures missiles, and part of the profits from the arms production go to the businessman's daughter Olga and her husband Zorikov in Prague.

"The Czech Republic should not serve as a base for people who benefit from Putin's war against Ukraine," Rakusan said today.

According to Aktualne.cz, Zorikov is a permanent resident of the Czech Republic and owns two apartments and several luxury cars in addition to his company in Zizkov.

The Czech Republic has so far placed three people on the national sanction list. Russian businessman Vladimir Yevtushenko and his son Felix Yevtushenko and Moscow patriarch Kirill. It did so because of their support for the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

For the people concerned, the inclusion in the sanctions list means a ban on entry into the Czech Republic, the prevention of any financial transactions through Czech entities and the freezing of any assets in the country.

The government is able to put people on the national sanction list on the basis of the "Magnitsky Act" aimed to improve the enforcement of human rights protection, which came into force the country in January. The Czech Republic will also propose names to be added to the EU sanction list.

The strange sanction at WTA Prague that vetoes Russian and Belarusian tennis players
613 字
2023 年 7 月 29 日
CE NoticiasFinancieras

英文
Copyright © Content Engine LLC
Clashes between Ukrainian sportswomen and Russian and Belarusian sportswomen are becoming more and more common in the world of sports. Tennis is one of the main scenarios where, due to its multiplication of clashes, the conflict between Ukraine and Russia after the Russian invasion is more evident. One of the most tense moments was experienced at Roland Garros, when the Belarusian Aryna Sabalenka, world number 2, defeated by a resounding 6-3 and 6-2 to the Ukrainian Marta Kostyuk, who refused to greet her because of the Ukrainian conflict, receiving boos from the stands in Paris. Elina Svitolina, also Ukrainian, opted for the same measure.

The Ukrainian, who has moved to Monte Carlo because of the war, says the world number two should answer the question of who she wants to win the war: "Let her say who she is going with. I have never said I hate her, but obviously I don't respect her. It's been 15 months since it all started and no Russian or Belarusian has taken any interest in my situation."

Likewise, at Wimbledon, where unlike last year the veto on Russian athletes was lifted, Belarusian Sabalenka admitted that she "was not going to talk about politics and was only going to talk about tennis." For his part, Daniil Medvedev said "I can't talk about what other players say, nor can I force them to say anything . If others don't want to speak out, that's their position. Mine is the same, I support peace, there is not much more I can add."

This time, the conflict escapes from the clutches of the WTA itself, the organization of the women's circuit, which stated that no tournament had in its power to veto players based on their nationality. And is that, as reported by the Associated Press, the Czech tournament will veto the entry of Russian and Belarusian players in a last-minute announcement that no one knew.

The tournament organizers themselves, however, have confirmed that this decision does not fall on their shoulders: it is due to the country's own decree. The Czech Republic has banned the access of Russian and Belarusian athletes to take part in any sporting competition within their country, all due to the invasion of Vladimir Putin's country into Ukrainian territory. It is the first professional tournament that will not allow the entry of players from these countries since the Tallinn WTA did so, as well as Wimbledon and the rest of British tournaments throughout last season.

In recent hours, according to the BBC, a Russian tennis player has been expelled from the country upon arrival at its borders, whose name has not been disclosed. This was reported by Miroslav Malý, director of the Central European tournament, who confirmed that the police had detained and expelled from the country a Russian player who had arrived in the Czech Republic without being aware of this situation.

Firm with non-transparent owners to supply oil to SSHR - server
627 字
2023 年 8 月 2 日 11:15 GMT
CTK Business News
CTK
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
adds statement by SSHR head Svagr in para 7,13, info on TAL pipeline in para 14

Prague, Aug 2 (CTK) - The State Material Reserves Administration (SSHR) has concluded a contract for the purchase of oil worth more than Kc1bn with Normeston Trading Limited, a Cyprus-based company whose owners are not transparent, Seznam Zpravy news server[https://www.seznamzpravy.cz/clanek/domaci-kauzy-stat-posle-miliardu-za-ropu-firme-za-niz-jsou-putinovi-prominenti-234636] reported today.

SSHR has checked the winner of the tender for the replenishment of oil reserves and has not violated the law, said its chairman Pavel Svagr.

"We have verified the owners as required by the public procurement law," he said.

"We have also asked some state authorities to cooperate (with us) in this regard to rule out the possibility that any of the owners are on the sanctions lists, for example," Svagr said.

Normeston also met the qualification criteria because it supplies oil to Hungarian company MOL and Slovak company Slovnaft, Svagr said.

The state will pay for the oil after delivery, and wants to sanction the company if it fails to meet the agreement.

"If you don't have a legal reason to exclude a company, if its owners are not on the EU sanctions list, you just don't exclude it," Svagr told CTK today.

The firm is controlled by a network of nine companies and funds from Cyprus, Hungary, Hong Kong and the British Virgin Islands, according to Seznam Zpravy.

Working with the anti-corruption organisation Transparency International (TI), the website identified four listed owners and SSHR confirmed that it considers these four to be the ones in the ownership structure.

"If the ownership structure runs through not just one, but three countries, where there is no problem to hide the real owner, then it is difficult to assume that the declared persons are the ones who really run the company," said Marek Chromy, an analyst at TI's Czech branch.

According to him, it is almost certain that these are the so-called professional white horses running the company in order to hide the real owners. One of such owners of the company is Cypriot lawyer Christodoulos Georgiou Vassiliades, who, according to the British government, helped the Russian oligarchs create offshore structures allowing them to hide their assets and evade the anti-Russian sanctions, Seznam Zpravy reported.

It is unclear where the Cypriot firm will get the oil for the Czech storage tanks, said the server. According to the contract, it is crude oil Rebco, which is exported by Russia.

In this context, Svagr told CTK that he also does not like the fact that petrol stations sell fuels that were mostly made from Russian oil. However, there is nothing that could be done about it for the time being. "Once the second IKL/TAL oil pipeline has enough capacity, we will not need Russian oil," Svagr said.

In July, the state-owned company Mero started design work on expanding TAL's capacity, which carries oil from Trieste, Italy, to Ingolstadt, Bavaria, and from there to the Czech Republic via the IKL pipeline. TAL should cover the Czech Republic's oil needs from 2025 onwards. Oil is also supplied to the country from Russia via the Druzhba pipeline.

SSHR has declared six tenders for the purchase of oil to replenish its emergency stocks. The previous five rounds had ended without success. Two companies, Normeston and Orlen Unipetrol, took part in the tender process, the former succeeding because of a better bid, SSHR said.

The government approved crude oil purchases last June due to a drop in oil emergency stocks below the required minimum. The European Union directive requires the countries that do not produce oil to have at least 90 days' supply.

Russian prosecuted for violating sanctions against oligarch
267 字
2023 年 8 月 7 日 10:31 GMT
CTK Daily News
CTKDAN
英文
(c) 2023 CTK (Ceska Tiskova Kancelar). All rights reserved.
Prague, Aug 7 (CTK) - Czech police are prosecuting a Russian citizen for violating international sanctions as he was involved in transferring money to a Russian oligarch on the EU sanction list since 2015 over Russia's annexation of Crimea, National Centre against Organised Crime spokesman Jaroslav Ibehej told CTK today.

According to Ibehej, the oligarch has long been associated with the top government officials of the Russian Federation.

The prosecution was launched by the National Centre against Organised Crime (NCOZ) on August 2. According to the agency, the Russian committed the crime, which consisted of transferring the oligarch's money, in 2015. "The funds were subsequently used on the territory of the Czech Republic," the spokesman said.

Police have carried out one search in the case, which is being supervised by the Prague Public Prosecutor's Office.

The man is being prosecuted at liberty.

Under the Czech Criminal Code, the violation of international sanctions carries a basic penalty of up to three years in prison or a fine. The offence is committed by anyone who violates to a large extent the sanctions that the Czech Republic has committed to meet within the UN or EU or that it has itself introduced under the sanction law.

The penalty is further increased depending on the amount of damage caused. If the perpetrator's act significantly contributes to the breach of international peace and security, the fight against terrorism or the promotion of democracy and the rule of law, he or she may be imprisoned for up to eight years.
